But it's charming throughout, right up to the big climax which sadly is a bit of a letdown. The movie deserved a better ending than the final confrontation which goes on so long that it all becomes a bit silly. For whatever disappointments there may be though there is enough here to make you look back on the film fondly. Wayne and O'Hara are terrific, and ably supported by a fine cast around them. The story has its flaws but it holds your attention throughout. And the film is shot so beautifully. The only thing more breathtaking than the Irish countryside may well be the Irish woman who stars in this memorable film.

With both the Duke, and Maureen O'Hara as his intended love interest plus John Ford returning to the land of his ancestors and directing in Technicolour, this has many ingredients of a decent Western. Whilst this isn't my favourite film to be filmed in - and about Ireland - David Lean's 'Ryan's Daughter' is, The Quiet Man remains one of the most loved, across all generations.With everything centred around the pub, the colourful characters and fights over women, this is has yet more Western ingredients. Winner of two Oscars (Ford as director and cinematography) plus two venerable and charismatic actors providing much of the irascible blarney - veteran Ford regular Victor McLaglen, though always playing Irish is actually from Kent, England and Barry Fitzgerald as the matchmaking tippler.If you've holidayed in Ireland, as I have, then that's a nice bonus as it brings back memories and, in for instance, the horse racing scene on the beach, the vast empty sands are a far cry to my jam-packed nearby beaches on the south coast. The scenery in this isn't always sunny and glossy - it's often a bit glum, with rain - this isn't a picture postcard from the Emerald Isle, but a rich slice of Irish life.John Wayne is measured and sedate as ex boxer Sean Thornton, who has some demons to conquer when he's continually goaded into a fight. Once he gets over them, the fisticuffs at the end are brilliantly - and amusingly staged and well worth waiting for. Maureen O'Hara is as radiant as ever and, dare I say it, the Duke actually looks comfortable as her suitor.My DVD copy (part of a 3 DVD set, with Rooster Cogburn and Stagecoach) is rather poor quality with a magenta fringe at times and rather a soft definition. I can't say whether transfer's differ for different releases. This does spoil one's enjoyment a bit but the strength of the film easily shines through.

reviews.review_title: I can decide which was more offensive.
reviews.content: Even with the understanding that this film was from a bygone era, I found the appalling treatment of women and the portrayal of Irish people as nothing but a bunch of brawling drunks completely offensive.  That, the ridiculous plot and cheesy acting (actors randomly going in and out of their `brogues') made viewing this film nearly impossible.  If you're interested in Irish culture and looking for an well-done, old film that well stands the test of time, try `Odd Man Out'.

In 1941, John Ford directed one of his best and most personal movies: "How Green Was My Valley" it was also his only Best Picture.The film was a nostalgic ride over a Welsh mining town shot in all black-and-white so both of the titular green and Maureen O'Hara fiery red hair were left to our imagination. The monochrome choice had also the merit to camouflage the Californian setting, as war made any overseas shooting impossible.Interestingly, despite the 'Welsh' cultural mark, the film was also a tribute to Ford's Irish ancestry. He even challenged purists by having many Irish actors play Welsh characters. It is possible that Ford thought this was the closest he would get to his roots so he let his sentimental self take the command of the camera. In 1951, he finally had the opportunity to honor Eire by adapting short story by Maurice Walsh, whose rights were bought in the early 30s.But how can one possibly imagine a tribute to Ireland in black-and-white or devoid of that so particular green? The Emerald Isle was a jewelry box out of which John Ford had to forge a gem... and it was "The Quiet Man", a film of temper and tenderness... and for once, a really green valley! You just can't cheat with the old country especially since no war has raised its ugly head to prevent Ford from taking a long vacation and bring his long-time partner John Wayne and the beautiful Maureen O'Hara for what would be one of his signature films.With "The Quiet Man", John Ford finally proves his statement right as he said: "None of my so called better pictures are westerns." I've enjoyed many of his Westerns but I admired the non-Western ones for the temperament they deployed without any fancy directing or elaborate storytelling, Ford just knew how to get the right effects. And "The Quiet Man" for that matter puts you immediately at ease, like the first sips of a pint of Guinness.Though the opening credits use a beautiful coastal view under a bright sunset, the film doesn't lay the green color at first but starts with the stranger's homecoming. Sean Thornton, the American coming back to his native Ireland and asking for a village named Insfree, a simple question that sets the tone and invite the first chuckles. So we'll deal with the colorful and sentimental Ireland and John Wayne didn't come to kick some ass or start some quarrel. In this appeasing mood, we appreciate his welcoming by the elfin-like Michaeleen played by the irresistible Barry Fitzgerald.The town's matchmaker (and occasional bookmaker) discovers that the big hunk of a man (one foot taller) is the little Sean he saw grow up and move to Pittsburgh, back to claim the land that belonged to his deceased parents, determined to start a new life in the green cradle. The exposition allows us to encounter in once all the players of that farcical melodrama. Ward Bond is the town priest. Catching Sean's eye is Maureen O'Hara as Mary Kate Danaher, the turbulent sister of Squire Will Danaher, a loud-mouthed self-centered bully (a scene-stealing over-the-top,Victor McLaglen) who won't have any outsider stepping on his territory, let alone the land he intends to buy from the rich Widow Sarah Tillane (Mildred Natwick).This will obviously complicate the love story going between Sean and Mary Kate, till marriage and even beyond. There might be bar brawls and big fistfights but maybe because there's always something worth all these shenanigans and deep inside, the Irish people are all proud of their traditions. Sean Thornton will learn at his expenses why America might have some roots in Ireland but is not Ireland. And it takes some great deal of courage from Wayne to play the part of a man branded as coward because in this cultural immersion.Of course he has his reasons and we know it's only a matter of time before the two distinguished gentlemen let the fists talk but "The Quiet Man" hides behind its comedic and romantic façade a great deal of knowledge about Ireland's traditions and the way they forged the temperament of many Americans whether born in the country or in America. There are many parts in the film that would be considered politically incorrect by our standards, but who would dare to call Wayne abusive or O'Hara submissive? The couple is certainly not mismatched when it comes to principles.Some would take a dowry as a symbol of oppressive patriarchy but Mary Kate isn't concerned with the money but what it represents, her emancipation, she's unchained by an institution like everyone else but not her free will. It's actually the men who learn humbling lessons in the film as if sometimes, one should consider the value of traditions before embracing everything from the modernity. Well, it's possible that the film has a few chauvinistic undertones but they never to be taken seriously, and well, sometimes the old-fashioned ways have their charm, and d it's precisely because a movie like "The Quiet Man" aged a lot that it feels so new and exhilarating.Ever since I discovered Ireland, I had a soft spot for that country and I envy those who have that tradition pumping in their blood, not denying mine of course, but it's a credit to John Ford to have made such a beautiful tribute to Ireland, visually and musically (that Victor Young's theme) that it probably made a few viewers, secretly wish they would be Irish.And just because nothing dramatic affects the film doesn't mean it's not entertaining and even thrilling in its own way, it's as quiet as its hero, calm and comprehensive on the surface but has with a few tricks under its sleeve... and knows how to make your heart pound, your jaw drop and your belly laugh!

reviews.review_title: shout it's praises to the high heavens
reviews.content: John Wayne is Sean Thornton who goes back to Ireland where he grew up to get away from his past as a boxer in America. He becomes smitten with beautiful Irish lass, Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara, who I never quite forgave for her slander of the late great John Ford) much to the chagrin of her older brother, Will. The rather simplistic plot isn't the reason that this film is great and has stood the test of time, but rather just the fact that it's a perfectly enchanting ode to Ireland in all her glory, the scenery is a sheer joy to behold, it's greatly acted by the cast, and brings a smile to anyone of Irish descent. A great little film on all accounts.My Grade: A DVD Extras: Commentary by Maureen O'Hara; "The Making Of The Quiet Man" 28 minute featurette from 1992; 30 minute "The Joys of Ireland" feauterette; Remembering the Quiet Man montage; Cast & Crew bios; Theatrical Trailer; and Trailers for "High Noon" & "Rio Grande"

One of my all-time favorite movies is THE QUIET MAN. If I happen to see it on TV my fingers release the remote and I'm captured by the story all over again. It is perhaps one of John Wayne's best films as well as perhaps the best film by director John Ford. And it's not even a western! If you've never seen the film it's the story of Sean Thornton (Wayne) who returns to the small village in Ireland where he grew up as a child to purchase the home he grew up in. Met by Michaleen Oge Flynn (Barry Fitzgerald) he isn't recognized but they soon become friends. Michaleen is basically the cab driver in town with his horse and carriage as well as a matchmaker of sorts.That comes into play when Sean catches a glimpse of Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara). Call it love at first sight the two are attracted by social customs of the time being what they are aren't allowed to meet. A bigger problem arises after Sean purchases his home to the dismay of Squire "Red" Will Danaher (Victor McLaglen), Mary Kate's brother who wanted the property for himself.When the town conspires to unite the young couple by tricking Will his anger takes over and he attempts to block their getting together. They do and eventually marry but Will refuses to pay Sean Mary Kate's dowry. While Sean could care less Mary Kate refuses to sleep with him until he takes care of the matter.What the townsfolk don't know, with one exception, is that Sean has refused to fight for a reason. When that final straw breaks the camel's back and he's had enough he changes his tune. All of this leads to a final showdown between the two men and one of the longest fight sequences ever put on film.The movie is a delight to watch over and over again. The performances are amazing to watch with all involved, from the smallest to largest roles, creating believable characters that you get mad at, laugh at and love by the end of the film. There are no truly small roles here.Ford creates not just a story but a setting that was familiar to him and the way he forms the combination of location and tale being told make it a location you'd love to visit. He brings his old Irish home to life for all to see and enjoy. The film is glorious to look at with some breathtaking scenery shot on location.With the numerous versions of this film released over the years why talk about it now and why discuss buying this latest edition? That's because Olive Films has come up with one of the best presentations of the film to date. As a part of their Signature Series the film has been mastered from a 4k scan of the original negative, offering the cleanest look the film has ever had.It also includes some interesting extras as well. Those include an audio commentary with John Ford biographer Joseph McBride, a tribute to Maureen O'Hara with Ally Sheedy, Hayley Mills, and Juliet Mills, DON'T YOU REMEMBER IT SEAN?: JOHN FORD AND THE QUIET MAN a visual essay by historian and John Ford expert Tag Gallagher, FREE REPUBLIC: THE STORY OF HERBERT J. YATES AND REPUBLIC PICTURES, THE OLD MAN: REMEMBERING JOHN FORD an appreciation of the director with Peter Bogdanovich and THE MAKING OF THE QUIET MAN written and hosted by Leonard Maltin.This is not just a movie to pick up and watch casually but one to enjoy over and over again. You'll find yourself cheering at the screen by the final sequence. You'll witness a beautiful love story filled with romance and a touch of humor. And you'll get to see one of the best movies ever made.

reviews.review_title: A nice going film looked overfunny and faltered in the entracte, because i don't know nothing about Ireland culture
reviews.content:
The Quiet Man (1952) :
Short Review -A nice going film looked overfunny and faltered in the entracte, because i don't know nothing about Ireland culture. The Quiet Man was a fun ride actually but i didn't expect it to be the one as i always seek for some quality work from John Ford. Here, John Ford wanted to have fun and so did i had fun too. What's more than that? Nothing. Just nothing. The Quiet Man was looking so good in the first 70 minutes when there's Homeland, Romance, Weeding but later it gets little sloppy due to unnecessary demands of the woman in the film. At one moment it looked like making a sense because the Dowry might have been more important for an Irish bride but scolding nice loving husband for that doesn't make any sense at all. As an addition to the senseless things the film suddenly turns over-funny and chaotic in the climax and i just felt like, What? Seriously, this was all they wanted since the beginning? All that beautiful romance, feelings for homeland were Just for the sake chaos in climax? The Quiet Man could have had better perception, for instance it could have been a well made love story or a woman's film but all they got to do is Irishmen laughters. And like I said i know nothing about Ireland culture so it never took me along. May be this is just made for the sake of Fun and I was mistakenly expecting something else. John Ford won Best Director Award at Oscars i am happy for him. John Wayne was good in lead role and Maureen O'hara looks gorgeous as redhead irish girl. The cinematography and locations are eye pleasing. That's it. Nothing more to say than i had fun but i am disappointed.RATING - 6/10*By - #samthebestest

John Ford may be the greatest director who ever lived. If he's not, he's in the top three. As great as many of his films are, none of them work as well as "The Quiet Man". This may be a perfect movie. The location photography is beautiful. The music is great. The cast is top-notch, with one Oscar caliber performance after another. There are a bunch of laughs and a lot of smiles in "The Quiet Man". I've seen this film a ton of times. It always feels new. The only thing that is different when I watch "The Quiet Man" now, as compared to my youth, is that when the cast says goodbye at the end of the movie, now I wave back.

reviews.review_title: Delightful Irish taming of the shrew
reviews.content: This is a wonderful movie, though not the typical western of actor John Wayne or director John Ford. Rather it's sort of an Irish rendition of Shakespeare's Taming of the Shrew, as others have also noted. Here we have the idyllic green Irish countryside, lovely Irish brogues, traditional Irish melodies, an engaging story, a touching romance, and some very compelling characters. This film delightfully blends comedy, romance, and drama...all three.The tale revolves around a former prizefighter, Sean Thornton, who has retired from boxing after accidentally killing a man in the ring. He was born in Innisfree but moved to America as a toddler. Upon returning to Ireland to buy the cottage where he was born and hopefully find peace, he glimpses a beautiful woman herding sheep in a meadow. He soon falls in love with this fiery Irish lass, Mary Kate Danaher, the town spinster and younger sister of the village bully, Squire 'Red' Will Danaher. Sean and Mary Kate marry, though against the wishes of Kate's older brother who wanted Sean's land for himself. When Will refuses to provide her dowry, Mary Kate insists that her husband fight her brother, forcing him to bestow what is rightfully theirs. Sean refuses because of his past boxing experiences, causing wild havoc in his marriage with this feisty spitfire. Mary Kate wants Sean to fight for her and that's all there is to it. Of course she is unaware of his past traumatic experience in the ring and simply believes her husband is a coward. No spoilers here as to whether Sean agrees to fight in order to gain his wife's respect. Suffice it to say that meanwhile, the townsfolk are all spoiling to see a brawl between Sean and his new brother-in-law. This is surely one of John Wayne's most sympathetic and endearing roles, here playing Sean Thornton, the ex boxer with the troubled past. The Irish born Maureen O'Hara is perfectly cast as the barefoot Mary Kate, a spunky lass with a fierce determination of her own. Their courtship on screen is sensuous, a sight to behold with its legendary windy kiss scene. Yes indeed, John Wayne is a a man who knows how to kiss a woman!In my opinion, complaints about spousal mistreatment in this movie are a bit of nonsense. Remember that when a villager offers Sean a stick to beat his wife, he throws it away even though he is livid with her at the time. It's the wife who gets her way here! Sean has his work cut out dealing with this spirited, strong willed lady who insists that her husband adapt to her culture, not the other way around. This is really quite a whimsical, entertaining, and uplifting gem, a true classic. I heartily agree with another's comment that it would make great St. Patrick's Day viewing. Surely this is Ireland at its most Irish.

reviews.review_title: Ireland meets Hollywood in classic style
reviews.content: A slice of the old country, the little people and the blarney is very much enjoyed in The Quiet Man. It's essentially a western set in Western Ireland but has all the beautiful detail one expects in Ford films.The plot follows that of the classic John Ford western meets Shakespeare's Taming of the Shrew.Stranger comes to town. Falls for the sister of the town's most powerful man who is also a tough fighting man. Conflict arises between stranger and local tough guy. A further conflict occurs between feisty femme and the stranger. The inevitable showdown happens. And the good guy wins the fight and tames the woman's spirit and thus wins her heart.The plot may sound basic, but the beauty of this film is in great locations, fine performances and a cracking script with plenty of the Irish humour and charm.Director Ford may only have had one eye and glasses but seemed to see much more than most with two eyes and 20-20 vision. It's his eye for the detail that make this movie especially memorable. Throughout the movie you feel like you are in the west of Ireland, almost one of the locals of Innisfree as you go inside the pub, the humble cottage, the church, the farmhouses and join the locals in the rolling greenery of the Irish countryside.The first confrontation between Sean Thornton (superbly played by John Wayne) and Red Will Danaher (equally good stuff from Victor McLaglan) has almost everything.The romance of the quaint Irish pub, the friendliness of the locals once Sean Thornton's identity has been revealed and the music starts - Wild Colonial Boy sung by none other than country and western singer Ken Curtis - Ford's real life son in law as the accordion playing Dermot Fahy. It hardly gets more Irish than this.Enter Red Will looking for fight. The punchy dialogue follows "I said good morning" Sean declares. "Yeah but it was good night you had in your mind" Red Will accuses Sean of making an ungentlemanly pass at his sister Mary Kate (Maureen O'Hara). The tension mounts.Ford's real life brother Francis Ford plays an old man in the pub and is central to this early scene - acting almost like a referee in between the two hulks of Sean and Red Will. In the end religious intervention in the form of the unlikely but convincing Ward Bond's Fr Lonnigan prevents a full-blown fistfight. But it is only delaying the inevitable. The tone is set.Ford assembled his usual supporting team to deliver this genuine movie treat. Maureen O'Hara who plays Mary Kate Danaher is at her radiant feisty best and probably never looked more beautiful in a movie. Then there is Barry Fitzgerald whose character is part leprechaun, part barfly and as the movie progresses he pops up as a jack of all trades - taxi service, matchmaker, bookmaker and even furniture removal man. He steals many scenes with his cheeky charm and his presence certainly adds to the myth that leprechauns may exist.It's certainly one of Ford's finest and has an epic fight at the end, which is not brutal, but merely cartoon violence that Tarantino would be proud of.So with wild Irish humour, accordion and loud piano music, jaunty pub songs, meaty confrontations, flames of red haired Irish folk and a big village to village fight, you might ask why this film is called The Quiet Man? Well here's the real conflict and the great irony of the title. Sean Thornton is a retired boxer and has returned to his hometown of Innisfree from Pittsburgh to enjoy "the quiet life". He gets anything but tranquillity and has to emerge from his conscience, morals and indeed motives, to fight for the right to have a quiet life and a beautiful wife (Maureen O'Hara) who is a shrew needing tamed as she prods her man to fight for her pride.The Quiet Man is a classic and one of Ford's standouts among his amazing canon of great work. He shows us a vibrant Ireland at it's finest in a movie that never tires. This is must for the DVD collection and whenever you're feeling down. Just insert disc, press play and let the great John Ford take you to the Emerald Isle and all it's wonderful wild romance.

reviews.review_title: Fist-fights and blarney! What more can you want?
reviews.content: "Well, then. Now. I'll begin at the beginnin'. A fine soft day in the spring, it was, when the train pulled into Castletown, three hours late as usual, and himself got off. He didn't have the look of an American tourist at all about him. Not a camera on him; what was worse, not even a fishin' rod." So begins "The Quiet Man", John Fords labour of love that turned a twee tale of Irish blarney into one of cinema's most passionate romances. When the Irish-American boxer Sean Thornton (John Wayne) kills an opponent in the ring, he returns home to the small rural village of his birth where he immediately purchases his old family cottage... An act that leads to him incurring the wrath of local squire Red Danaher (Victor McLagen). Their feud is escalated when Sean meets Danahers feisty, beautiful sister Mary-Kate (Maureen O'Hara) and they quickly embark upon a tempestuous romance. The assorted locals conspire in this courtship but the stubborn Danaher continues to block the road to happiness. With such flamboyant stock character actors as Ward Bond, Barry Fitzgerald and Mildred Natwick on typically barnstorming form, what Ford presents here is a loving, charming depiction of the whimsical rural Ireland of his imagination. An idealised homeland full of larger than life characters, strong women, hard-drinking men and innocent parochial religion and a place where and all disputes can be happily resolved with a fistfight. And boy what a fistfight! Words such as "lyrical" and "mythic" are often applied to the directors work and this was probably never more apparent than here. From the first sighting of Mary-Kate in the tree encircled glade through to the final secretive whisper between man and wife, there can be few films as brimming with undiluted joie de vivre as "The Quiet Man".

reviews.review_title: An Irish Person Not Loving A Film Set In Ireland? OH THE HORROR!!
reviews.content: Just to explain the title, I am an Irish person, so I may be overexposed to this film, since everyone told me that this film was brilliant.How can such an interesting premise be so boring? Trust me, that 2hr 9m will seen a lot longer. The whole time I was waiting for the satisfying conclusion, waiting for the fun to begin...then the credits rolled. If you asked me to analyze a scene I wouldn't be able to even as I watched it!

reviews.review_title: Mostly-dull soap opera with great scenery
reviews.content: Mostly-dull soap opera with great scenery. Started off interestingly enough but quickly degenerated into a backwards and forwards game of romantic intrigues, many of which don't make sense. They might have made sense in a different day and age, but today they just seem very weird and old-fashioned, and like intrigues for the sake of intrigues.Scenery is great, of course. Cinematography doesn't do it all the justice it deserves though, by today's standards. Resolution and focus are not that great. Might be a function of being made in 1953. A bit of remastering will go a long way.Role of romantic lead is a bit of a departure for John Wayne and he performs it well. Maureen O'Hara is great in the female lead. Good supporting cast.Certainly no issues with the performances. It's the plot that lets this movie down.

reviews.review_title: Cute, but not the best classic ever
reviews.content: The Quiet Man is a very famous classic that's worth a watch, if you like to watch famous, revered classics. John Ford won Best Director during the 1952 Oscar ceremony, and the cinematography was rewarded as well, since the movie was filmed entirely on location in Ireland. The beautiful green meadows in Technicolor are some of the most famous aspects of the film.The other, much more famous part of the movie is the famous kiss scene between John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara. You've probably seen it; the wind is blowing fiercely around them and Maureen slaps his face so hard she actually broke her wrist during the take. After such a feisty refusal, she tells him off in true Irish style, then kisses him back. It's a very cute scene, one that's often cited among the greatest of onscreen romances.The rest of the movie centers on John and Maureen's romance, her family's objections, and the disapproval of an American in the small Irish village. There's a pretty famous fistfight that comes from The Quiet Man, and John and Maureen continue to trade blows throughout the film, but it's far from the typical western you'd normally find John Wayne in. It's entertaining, but unless you're in love with your Irish heritage, it probably won't be your favorite.

.I've always loved Maureen O'Hara, but John Wayne is just not who I would pick opposite her. He's dull and not very exciting. She needs someone more like Brian Keith (who played opposite her in "Parent Trap").I've read books that used "The Taming of the Shrew" as a guide, but this movie just doesn't cut it for me.

reviews.review_title: A quaint and largely pleasant watch
reviews.content: John Ford is an interesting director nowadays, because while his influence is undeniable, many of his movies haven't aged as ideally as work from some of the other filmmakers of his time. When younger film fans talk about directors from decades upon decades ago, they're more likely to bring up Billy Wilder, or Akira Kurosawa, or Fritz Lang, or even Ingmar Bergman. I would have to share that sentiment, in a way, because I think all of those (and others) have made films that are just more exciting by today's standards. No one director from that long ago has a filmography that's aged perfectly, and some things are unavoidable when it comes to potentially offending an audience 70 or 80 years after your film is released. But when it comes to pacing, and excitement, and creating characters that are compelling, I feel like Ford is lacking when compared nowadays to some of his contemporaries.I like a lot of John Ford movies. I liked The Quiet Man. But so far I haven't loved any of them, and yeah, The Quiet Man is another to add to that list of liked and not loved. If we're returning once more to those directors I mentioned before, I love Sunset Boulevard and Some Like It Hot, I love Seven Samurai and Ikiru, I love Metropolis, and I love Fanny & Alexander, to name a few films from what was already a small batch of directors. It's hard to come up with a brief, concrete reason why I don't connect to Ford's filmography quite as strongly, and even harder to come up with a reason why a good deal of people around my age don't seem to love his films either.I guess they can be slow. Just a tiny bit too slow, because I approach most older movies willing to be a little more forgiving when it comes to pacing. But The Quiet Man comes in at about 130 minutes, and has an overall very straightforward story. I don't think the length helped in this case, but again, at least it wasn't stretched to the length of an epic, which I'm sure Ford could have done if he'd wanted, given how much of a big name he was. There is some tremendously pretty scenery to look at- I was taken aback, in all honesty, the first time the Irish landscape was shown in all its glory. The lighting and colours and composition all made it look so crisp and tangible, more-so than just about any other movie I can think of from that time period. It was almost as if they'd taken some HD digital cameras back in time and filmed it that way.The other big problem that holds The Quiet Man back from greatness, besides its pacing, is the love story. I know it's far from the only film to do this, but the way the two main characters instantly fell in love was a bit preposterous. Maybe it was easier to stomach back in the 1950s, but watching it now, you're kind of dying for some sort of explanation. Did they have a past they forgot about? Is there some other force pushing them together? Can they at least have a truly passionate, credible talk between each other regarding why they feel the way they do? Can they cheekily acknowledge just how crazy it is that they were so instantly attracted? John Wayne looks distractingly older than O'Hara too, and so even the idea that they're both just really physically attracted to each other is a little hard to believe. At least that shot of their first kiss is so memorably staged and shot that it ALMOST makes you forget for a moment or two how sudden their feelings are.Anyway, get past that, and you're left with some good stuff. It's funny in parts, it has a unique setting, it's amazingly well shot, there's an extended horse race in the countryside which is a lot of fun (and makes the film feel, momentarily, like an Irish western), and the performances are overall pretty good. Wayne is his usual self and he's fine, but O'Hara really shines, and she has an amazing screen presence. Most of the supporting cast playing a variety of quirky, endearing, but undoubtedly stereotyped Irish-folk are pretty good too.It's worth a watch if you don't mind older films and the slow pacing, simple stories and characters, and potentially problematic values that come with them. The Quiet Man certainly has examples of the last of those, I should mention. I tried not to let the fairly casual jokes about domestic violence affect by view of the movie too much, but I know some people are more offended by poorly aged jokes than I might be, so it's worth pointing that out. I don't think it's quite a stone cold classic, but it's mostly likeable and engaging, as well as one of the better John Ford films I've seen, and overall, there are far worse ways to spend just over two hours.

My second favourite film after Hobsons ChoiceI suppose it is a nostalgic look at old Ireland but I love it just the same. Barry Fitzgerald plays a wonderful part as does Victor McLagan Sadly films like this are not made any more. It is naive but gives you a feeling ofhope in the sense of the simplicity of life as it should be. The screenplay is excellent. The scenery is spectacular. John Wayne plays second fiddle to the beautiful Maureen O' Hara. The fight scene at the end is a wonderful climax. The old man rising from his deathbed caps it all.

Sean Thornton, played by John Wayne, returns from America to claim his homestead in Ireland.  He finds his bride in Mary Kate played by Maureen O'Hara, but is hampered by her brother, Victor McGlaglen who tries to keep them apart.  This is a poignant beautiful story with lots of gay Irish songs sung by Barry Fitzgerald and company in fine voice.  I had never seen this before and glad I did because it is a wonderful production directed by the illustrious John Ford.  To some people it might seem too long, but the story and the photography is gorgeous.  Highly recommended!

One of the other comments starts with the declaration that the author really doesn't like John Wayne. Well, I do and all the manliness that he brought to the screen. Cowboy isn't an insult and neither is manly. If we could see past the pretty boys (and we should given what most of them start looking like at 40 when they add botox to their drugs of choice) who litter the screen today, we would be better able to appreciate the Johns (Ford and Wayne) who understood and portrayed what works in a movie, in a relationship and for a culture (Irish, American, Scots, Siamese, etc., etc.)Thank TCM for keeping this gem available and making sure that those of us now surrounded by George (Clooney, not Washington) and Brad (the pits), see what we are missing. How about an honorary Oscar for that loveliest of screen lasses? Now is the time.

Unquestionably John Ford's best. Endearing as it is enduring. Ford's humorous vision of Ireland was really taken from the period around the turn of the century. Understandably upsetting as a vehicle for stereotypes to some residents of that wonderful country, but mostly an object of amusement to the general population. And to all the perpetually pre-offended idiots that call this incredibly perfect movie "sexist and brutal" my sincerest apologies. I feel terrible for having loved this movie for the last 40 years. I'm happy to report that I've already enrolled in sensitivity training and in just a few weeks I'm sure I'll be mad as hell about John Wayne tossing Maureen O'Hara on the bed too. I feel better already. Jeez! 10/10

Most of the characters in this film beheave very unrealistically or sterotypically, drawing a distinct awareness to the fakeness of the story. Nearly all of the actors overact so greatly that it only serves to make the film feel even more unrealstic.Wayne was the only character that wasn't over acted. His cool devil-may-care drawl was probably cast as a contrast to the Irish countryside, but the extreme overacting from everyone else mkaes him look far more than a little out of place, and it makes me wonder if Wayne was mislead into accepting this role.The only reason I finished this movie was because the film is most well-known for its lengthy climactic fist fight. While it may have been lengthy compared to other films of the time, it's interrupted by many other scenes that make the actual on screen fighting very short, not to mention painfully obvious that the fighting was staged and the actors involved were actively trying to avoid hurting each other.

reviews.review_title: Too Quiet to Be Completely Successful.
reviews.content: Former U.S. boxer John Wayne returns to his homeland of Ireland and immediately falls in love with Maureen O'Hara in this watchable, but highly over-rated film from Oscar-winning director John Ford. Naturally Wayne locks horns with O'Hara's older brother (Oscar-nominee Victor McLaglen). Two camps, one for Wayne and one of McLaglen, soon develop in the small community and a whacked fight between the two is the only solution in the end. A really ho-hum movie that is good-looking with beautiful cinematography that ultimately falls flat by its final act. Wayne and O'Hara are all right. In fact everything is all right, but the film could have been so much more. Wayne's dark boxing career is not given near enough screen-time. Barry Fitzgerald is the best performer in a limited part. 4 stars out of 5.

This charming film is not only a feast for the eyes, but quite possibly John Ford and John Wayne's best collaboration.Filmed primarily in the lush green Irish countryside, this Technicolor masterpiece is a symbol of post-World War II Hollywood at its best. It may also have some deeper symbolism  more on that, later!(CONTAINS SPOILERS)In one of his better performances, John Wayne plays Sean Thornton, an Irish-American, who returns to his childhood (and ancestral) home in a small Irish village. He falls in love with and marries a beautiful, but fiery-tempered redhead, Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara), with the aid of town bookie and busybody Michaeleen Flynn (Barry Fitzgerald), who doubles as the traditional Irish `matchmaker.' The antagonist is Mary Kate's stubborn brother, Red Will Danaher (Victor McLaglen), who has taken to having his henchmen call him `Squire Danaher.'The story is a familiar one: After winning Mary Kate's hand, the Americanized Thornton fails to understand the importance of his bride's dowry, which her brother refuses to give. A former heavyweight boxing contender, he had left the ring in horror after accidentally killing an opponent. He had vowed never to  fight anyone again. Because of this vow, he allows the arrogant Will to taunt and bully him, not realizing that his bride is being equally humiliated. Finally realizing the situation, Thornton rides to the train station, reclaims his wife and drags her unceremoniously (through actual sheep dung, we are told in Leonard Maltin's trailer about the making of the film) back to her brothers' farm, to demand the money. Sean and Will square off in a rowdy fist fight that has the entire town watching and placing bets.The Quiet Man is an absolute joy to watch. Of course the Technicolor brilliance, under the hands of the master Ford and his Technicolor wizard Winton C. Hoch, captures the brilliance of the Irish countryside and O'Hara's untamed red-headed sex-appeal. The accents themselves add to the charm. One finds oneself thinking with an Irish brogue for hours afterward.Yet the real beauty of The Quiet Man is its combination of innocence and sex-appeal-or perhaps that should be phrased `innocence and romantic tension.' While the film's genteel innocence today makes it seem a bit precocious, we must remember that it was pushing the envelope just a tad for 1952. Ohio viewers, in fact, didn't get to see the brief but classic scene of Flynn shaking his head and muttering as he notices the broken wedding bed  not knowing, of course, that it was broken by Sean angrily flinging Mary Kate onto it, rather than by the means he no doubt imagined. The bed, in fact, came into play more than once. When the huge bed was being delivered, Mary Kate and one of her younger brothers looked on. The brother remarked `Is that a bed or a fairground?' then added to his sisters' embarrassment, `A man would have to be quite a sprinter to catch his wife in that bed!'Wayne and O'Hara have wonderful chemistry. One of Wayne's children remarked (in the Maltin trailer) that his father was an actor who came off the screen, larger than life, and that O'Hara was one actress who could match him. Tough, hot-tempered and determined, yet inwardly fragile, she captures the complex Mary Kate as she battles warring emotions and tries to break through the cultural wall that threatens to permanently mar the new marriage. She also shows some real athleticism in the film.The writing and the cast are outstanding. Fitzgerald was already probably the best known Irish-American actor and he definitely delivers again as the busybody drunk, Flynn. His tipsy attempts to retain the dignity and decorum of the matchmaker while interceeding with Mary Kate, on Sean's behalf, is endearing.McLaglen, meanwhile, is the perfect spoil. A big, loud, rude, well-to-do farmer, he has had his own way in the small village too long to stand by and watch Sean Thornton march in and buy his ancestral home from the neighboring Widow Tillane (Mildred Natwick). The fight scene is a classic.The various townspeople and saloon patrons give the picture a very authentic Irish feel. So do the two clergymen, Father Peter Longergan (Ward Bond), who doubles as the narrator, and the Protestant vicar, Reverend Playfair (Arthur Shields) and his devoted wife (Eileen Crowe). The Catholic priests' leadership in organizing a cheering crowd for the vicar, while his superior (whom he fears may transfer him) is visiting is a charming touch.At least I considered it merely a charming end to the film until a thought hit me. This WAS Ireland! This brings home another big question  was Ford, whose blood went back to the Emerald Aisle, making any political/religious statements in the film? Throughout the story, the home rule crowd is depicted by Flynn and his younger saloon friends, as good-hearted drunks who provide neither danger to the crown, nor hope to its foes. Later, the Irish Republican Army is even mentioned, and even then, in somewhat good humor.Perhaps the ending gives a clue, though. Father Longergan not only leads the cheering for his Protestant rival, but momentarily hides his collar as the vicar and his superior ride past. Perhaps Ford, indeed, is suggesting that Ireland could be at peace  or at least, that the political strife could be separated from religious differences, if all parties would swallow their pride (cover their collar) and lend a hand to those on the other side. Of course, this may be reading too much into Ford's work.Political meaning or not, The Quiet Man is one for the ages. This is probably my favorite John Wayne film and one of my all-time favorites. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

reviews.review_title: Sometimes You Gotta Use Your Fists
reviews.content: The plot is about an American who returns to his Irish ancestral homeland and buys his ancestral home for far more than it was worth. This happens to annoy a local man who wanted the land, and said man is more annoyed when the American falls in love with his sister, and she with him. The problem is presumably resolved when the American marries the sister, while the brother expects to marry the young widow who owned the land-but the widow refuses to marry the man, and the offended brother refuses to pay the promised dowry to his sister. The American tries to convince his new bride that the dowry is unimportant, but she is adamant as a matter of principle. Either he must fight his brother-in-law, or face contempt from both the townspeople and his wife.Yet there is one problem-the American turns out to be a former boxer who accidentally killed an opponent, and who in fact went to Ireland in the first place to leave this past behind him. Now instead of the happy quiet existence he hoped to have, he is forced to consider doing what he hoped never to do again. What to do? The answer is all too predictable, and admittedly the story has an overly happy Hollywood ending. But still the performers excel (even John Wayne, whom I don't usually like), and one sees what it is like to face an unwanted moral dilemma.

I found this movie really shocking.The main topic may be interesting, i.e. the clash between the liberal American culture and the very catholic and traditional Irish one. In the beginning, this seems so work; the humor is not exactly sophisticated, but you can smile at a couple of jokes. Of course, you notice from the beginning the really bad performance of nearly all the actors; some second roles are interesting however.But with the progression of the movie, it looks more like a promotion of violence against women disguised by thick and rough so called "humor", rather than a romantic comedy. In my opinion, this is not funny at all; the perspective of the movie clearly is to play down sexism and violence against women; women in this movie even seem to like this kind of masculinity. The last thing to mention is the unbearable music: however, it goes well with the rest of the movie.

reviews.review_title: Sir!... Sir!... Here's a good stick, to beat the lovely lady.
reviews.content: As soon as I saw Barry Fitzgerald, I was transported to that scene in Going My Way where he meets with his elderly mother from Ireland. There are no tear-jerking moments in this film, which is full of laughs.The film is known for being the second collaboration between John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara. This collaboration started in 1951 with Rio Grande, and followed by this film, Wings of Eagles, McClintock, and Big Jake. These two made the perfect couple.The film was shot in Ireland for all the exterior shots. The beauty of that country and the great music made it a timeless film that can be enjoyed over and over.

reviews.review_title: A John Wayne, John Ford Classic
reviews.content: John Wayne, Maureen O'Hara, Ward Bond, Barry Fitzgerald, Victor McLaglen -- the cast is loaded with talent beyond any normal expectations. John Ford could hardly hope for a better combination with the Irish countryside and a fanciful script. This film has remained in memory since its release in 1952. If that doesn't indicate quality entertainment, what does?

reviews.review_title: Don't miss this John Wayne-Maureen O'Hara pairing, directed by John Ford
reviews.content: John Ford won his fourth and last Best Director Oscar (the film also won for its Color Cinematography) for this, another successful pairing of John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara, whose famous face slapping attempt is featured in TCM & Chuck Workman's 100 Years at the Movies (1994) short. She broke her hand when Wayne blocked her blow, and had to act in the rest of the movie without a cast!This part comedy, part romance drama includes an excellent supporting cast: Barry Fitzgerald, Ward Bond, Mildred Natwick, and Victor McLaglen (who was nominated for a Best Supporting Actor Oscar), among others. The film, co-produced by Ford and Merian C. Cooper was also nominated for Best Picture, Best Screenplay (Frank Nugent's only Academy recognition, for adapting Maurice Walsh's story), Color Art Direction-Set Decoration, and Sound (Daniel Bloomberg's last film). #76 on AFI's 100 Greatest Love Stories list. Added to the National Film Registry in 2013.Wayne plays American boxer Sean Thornton, who's returned home to Ireland. He falls for the beautiful red-headed lass Mary Kate Danaher (O'Hara), whose brother Squire 'Red' Will Danaher (McLaglen) isn't so keen on Sean. In fact, the two have fighting words that eventually lead to an extended brawl, which covers a lot of ground and is followed by cheering members of the community. Fitzgerald plays one of these, Michaleen Oge Flynn, while Bond plays Father Peter Lonergan.

There may not be a more energetic movie than THE QUIET MAN.  The music, the physical action, the lush color (for Republic, almost shocking)...and the innuendo!  The references to "knowing" each other (especially when the priest sees the broken bed, and reacts in kind) and the cultural barriers that inhibit their love make this film 'sexier' than any soft-core epic out today.

reviews.review_title: A visual treat for everyone that's Irish, and all those who wish they were Irish
reviews.content: John Ford's 1952 film classic, "The Quiet Man", speaks out as his directorial thank-you to his Irish background. Perhaps, the film could not be made today, because of its downplay of the place women hold in society, but be that as it may, it is a film classic, and meant to be enjoyed on days when one wishes to sit back nd take in the laid-back lifestyle of another land.John Wayne uses a good amount of acting talent to play the role of Sean Thorton, an Irish born native son who went to America, became a professional boxer, and during a bout, killed his opponent in the ring. This cloud hangs over him, he leaves America, and returns to his native town, Innisfree, where he vows to never fight in anger again.In his home town, he meets up with Mary Kate Dannaher, played by Maureen O'Hara. These two had an undeniable screen chemistry, and it certainly came out in this picture. Wayne wishes to marry Mary Kate, but he has riled her brother, Big Will Dannaher, played by Ford stalwart, Victor McLaglen, who refuses to permit such a union. In Ireland, the oldest brother, if there was no father, could take this action.Eventually, thanks to the efforts of the local matchmaker, played by Barry Fitzgerald, and the local priest, played by Ward Bond, Sean and Mary Kate are able to marry, but Will refuses to hand over her dowry, Sean refuses to fight for the dowry, and the Irish landscape begins to boil over.Eventually, matters do come to a head, or fist, between Sean and Dannaher, in a wild, woolly, brawl that starts in an open field on the Dannaher property, goes over the countryside, spills into the nearby town, and in typical Irish manner, ends up in a local pub. The final punches are thrown, and peace ultimately comes to White O'Mornin', the birth home of Sean.If one wishes to enjoy a film dedicated to the Irish, this classic is it. A good 9/10

reviews.review_title: Not one of John Ford's best
reviews.content: Although The Quiet Man has traditionally had a place on the top of John Ford's career, I found it to be second, or maybe even third tier Ford. I've seen more than a dozen that I prefer to it, with only two that are on its low level, none really below (however, I like them all). The story here is uninteresting. John Wayne moves to his homeland of Ireland from the U.S., buys back his family home, and courts a young woman (Maureen O'Hara). Her brother (Victor McLaglen) must approve of the marriage, but he refuses. Later in the film townspeople trick him into giving his siter to Wayne in marriage, which starts a bitter feud. The film is played for romance and comedy, and only moderately succeeds in both sectors. It begins very romantically, but as soon as O'Hara's part expands, she immediately becomes overbearing, annoying, and somewhat psychotic. I sure as hell wouldn't want anything to do with that woman. And John Wayne does little with his character. The role is underwritten, with a particularly flimsy backstory. Wayne is generally a very good actor in Ford's films, but he has little to do and, more or less, just stumbles through the entire film. He actually gets pretty mean to O'Hara late in the film, but I disliked her character so much that I almost approved of the scene where Wayne drags her over the landscape on her butt.The supporting cast has better luck. Barry Fitzgerald especially shines, and Ward Bond, Victor McLaglen, and many others whose names I didn't catch were good, too.Perhaps the best reason to watch the film is for the beautiful color cinematography. It catches the country of Ireland well. The music is also quite beautiful.Overall, The Quiet Man does have some great scenes, but there's generally little of interest happening. It's rather overlong at 2 hours and 9 minutes. A lot of other Ford films are more worthy, The Grapes of Wrath, My Darling Clementine, The Searchers, The Wagon Master, the list could go on for nearly a mile. The Quiet Man gets a 7/10, which is quite unimpressive for such a beloved film from such a wonderful director.

My wife, also being an Irish Mary Kate and being born on the same day as Maureen O'Hara, started a tradition several years ago watching The Quiet Man on St. Patrick's Day. We both love the Irish character of this movie. By far one of our favorite classics.

reviews.review_title: Of COURSE it's about violence - just be sure to get the whole message
reviews.content: To say that this film "promotes wife-beating" is beyond preposterous. The worst thing John Wayne does to Maureen O'Hara is to give her a largely symbolic and clearly harmless 'boot in the backside' - something which by that point in the film her character has richly earned. This is no more violent nor misogynistic than, say, the opening scene in The Philadelphia Story. Or scenes in many, many other films that show men and women roughhousing with each other, essentially by mutual consent.Furthermore, to see this film as *promoting* violence, against women or anyone else, is to miss it's main point, by a country mile. This is a film about exactly that peculiar cultural norm, in which violence becomes sublimated into traditions of friendship and caring. It's a film that suggests how our violent natures and our violent past are evolving.Even the title should make this obvious. John Wayne's character is so appalled by violence that he's run as far away from it as he can, to what he views as a garden of Eden. But the seeds of violence remain in his nature, and in those around him. What makes the Ireland of this film an Eden indeed is how the culture has turned malicious violence into a formality, a sort of stylized ritual of friendship.One could say that this is a criticism of Ireland, and perhaps an unwarranted one. Of course, it's not. It could not be more obvious that Ford is using a mythic Ireland to make a point about all of human culture in the mid-20th Century. He suggests that perhaps we are violent animals, but that denying our nature isn't the right answer. He suggests that a healthy culture uses tradition to formalize conflict and allow it to play out in a benign and even creative way.Wayne at first fails to understand that this ritualized 'violence' is not the real thing. That it conveys love, not malice. That it's a peculiar but lively tradition, which acts as a conduit for the relationships of both men and women.Whether all this takes place in anything resembling the 'real' Ireland is obviously irrelevant. This Ireland of Ford's fond remembering is as real as Hilton and Capra's Shangri-La. It's a heaven that we all seek. In a way, Ford's Ireland is an answer to Hilton's. Ford asserts that a paradise that depends on humans acting like angels is unrealistic. We need a paradise where we can acknowledge our darker side, and turn it into a positive thing.Does Ford succeed in making that point? That's another question... But I would say that he does, brilliantly. The Quiet Man is a love story, a story of deep friendship - between the two supposed antagonists, Wayne and McLaglen, who are clearly destined to be devoted friends. Moreover, The Quiet Man is a brilliant evocation of every human's personal quest for a separate peace, a place where they can be themselves, only better.The Quiet Man is one of the greatest masterpieces of film, always in my own top five. It's also one of the most enjoyable, uplifting films of all time. If you emerged from it with any other feeling than joy, you brought that feeling in with you, and simply refused to let go of it.

When I first saw this movie in the late sixties, I was already a big fan of John Wayne's westerns. I stumbled upon this gem during a snowstorm, sitting by the fire, on a Saturday afternoon. Still the best way to watch a movie at home. The film is pretty light-hearted without being too foolish and silly. You get to see the beautiful Irish countryside and a slower pace of life. I want to fish that stream where Father Lonergan was! The film slowly works up to its climax, the confrontation between Squire Danaher and Sean Thorton. The fight scene is pretty tame by today's standards but it was filmed in 1952. May not be everyone's taste, but if you like John Ford films, the Duke, or old movies, it may be worth your time.

A friend lent me this tape as I had just returned from a trip to Ireland. It's one of her favorite movies.  I just found it too dull for words, and horribly cliched.  At times it was somewhat incoherent, and it took far too long to get to the point (which was minimal as it was).  Even the beautiful Irish scenery was corrupted by what I assume was poor use of Technicolor. I think it has been very overrated.

Irish-American ex-boxer Sean Thornton (John Wayne) moves back to Ireland where he promptly falls in love with red-haired colleen Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara) while making an enemy of her blustering tough-guy brother, Squire "Red" Will Danaher (Victor McLaglen). Drinking, singing, and brawling ensue as various romances get straightened out. Directed by John Ford (and including a number of his usual players, such as Ward Bond), the technicolour cinematography is excellent, the score great, and the story entertaining. The style, especially the sentimentality and broad humour, has not aged well, and while Wayne makes a great brawler, he's a bit weak playing a frustrated husband. Maureen O'Hara is good as the fiery red-head but doesn't do much to raise the character beyond cliché (the same is true for Barry Fitzgerald's quaint whisky-loving matchmaker/bookmaker). All in all, a great plug for taking a vacation on the Emerald Isle and a fun, lightweight film that needs to be considered in context (because it has elements sure to offend a broad swath of modern sensibilities).

First off, I got to reply to some of the posters here who have stated they dislike John Wayne. Yea, I agree he was no Marlon Brando or William Holden and he never shed a tear(that I recall) but he was a real man. He never appeared to be acting, but merely being himself. That was the appeal of him. He never claimed nor acted like he was different from you or me. Not all caught up with being an enigma like James Dean or marlon Brando..just a regular guy who usually played the part of a man called upon to be courageous and brave. Now on to this gem of film! Too many great scenes and lines to write 'em all down! And the Michelinni character..the little guy who drives the buggy and gave JW the lift from the train station..he was a hoot! Irish folklore is among the richest and most interesting in this world. And finally, one can not understate the authentic and angelic beauty of Maureen O'Hara. She radiates such beauty and romance with her eyes alone that todays actresses can take off ALL their clothes and hardly come close to what she could with a mere glance! Simplistic? Today's world much to complex and sophisticated to ever put out a movie like this? I don't think it so much as sophistication as it that our minds have been dulled and polluted with seeing everything that was once held sacred. Kids today know more about sex at 10 y.o. than we did before we were 21! It is sad that a movie like this would not appeal to the youth of today because no one gets naked or there are no cuss words! Pity! Pity!

A retired American boxer (John Wayne) returns to the village where he was born in Ireland, where he finds love.Who can say anything bad about director John Ford? Or actor John Wayne? Surely not I. Though, there is some strange thing about Wayne's complete lack of accent. Sure, he spent his life in America, so that ought to explain it. But it is pretty funny to say he was born in Ireland and has absolutely nothing Irish in his voice to show for it.The story itself is generally good and it is fun to revisit these old classics. Of course movies today (2015) are bigger, but not always necessarily better. The old films bring us a sense of escapism that just no longer exists... bless them.

I recently visited many of the shooting locations of my favourite movie, The Quiet Man, in the west of Ireland and published a travel feature with photos (I'm a travel journalist). My Quiet Man blog can be read at tomsweeneytravels. blogspot. com I stayed at Ashford Castle where John Ford, John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara stayed during the shoot, which was a perfect base for touring the area and reliving the magical moments seen on screen. Even if you're not a huge fan of the movie, a visit to this beautiful part of the world could easily send you rushing out to buy the DVD. My blog article is both informative and my personal tribute to a movie I first saw 40 years ago and have been in love with ever since.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful Power of the wills of Romance AND that "Irish" temper ...
reviews.content: This is one my favorite movies for many reasons. One being the lovely, ongoing (from movie to movie) struggle between two of the most heard headed Actors' or Actress' that click together romantically, and otherwise that I know of, this team of Maureen O'Hara and John Wayne! I look forward to any movie outing where i see them together, but this movie "The Quiet Man" is my favorite!I almost died with laughter when in a VERY romantic and old-fashioned style, Sean aka John Wayne throws the hot-heated, single-minded " I want me about Sean, and I if I don't have your man at all!" as she weeps.Tensions build and much plotting in this wonderful little village of Innis free, Ireland, until finally Ms O'Hara hops on a train to leave.Well with tiny town precision the message travels to Sean and he finally loses his temper (there is a subplot of two as to why he didn't) and he Grabs Her directly out of the train with the townspeople following, one precocious old lade applauding him and saying "Can I get ye a good stick for the lady sir?!" I almost died laughing, as Maureen was terribly unhappily and Very much was over his shoulder and pinned, kicking a screaming in a rather risqué moment or so for kiddies, as swats, though endearing certainly threatened! limo.This tiny little movie is more than just a slice of life, it is full of life. I adore the movie even when I thought at fist "The Duke" as an Irish son coming home to his ancestry was more than a stretch, but He made it work. Maureen O'Hara wins my heart as the best actor/actress in this movie though that is a tough call. The characterization within a real Irish setting are almost fanciful, but nor.I give this movie 5stars out of five! I have worn out one VHS, now onto Cd's-Hope you enjoy this action, romantic and character of a fine and wonderful film!

One of my all time favourite films, although it can be disparaged for it Paddy whackery here in Ireland. Not by any feat of the imagination could this ever be called a factual representation of Ireland in the 1920's but it is the directors love letter to the country of his birth. John Wayne as Sean Thornton is superb, his presence, his swagger and of course Maureen O Hara as fiery Mary Kate just radiates throughout this film.  The music is fabulous from the de-de-de-de of the Rakes of Mallow to the way the crowd bursts into The Wild Colonial Boy with such harmony in the bar. John Wayne also utters one of my favourites quotes from a movie in this film "There'll be no locks and bolts between us Mary Kate except those in your own mercenary little heart"-pure poetry.

Who doesn't love John Wayne? And Maureen O'Hara? Wow! Those two had chemistry and no mistake.Good friends in life they paired on screen better than most. Funny, sometimes silly, this movie still stands as great entertainment in the battle of the sexes.Although a bit thin in plot you quickly catch on that Sean Thornton is home to stay and the amusing wrangling to buy back the family home play out in the most satisfying set up for brother "Squire Danaher" to be at loggerheads with Sean as he attempts to woo his darlin' Mary Kate Danaher, sister of the Squire himself.The sparks do fly but all too quickly the story is told and we are left only to smile as the ups and downs are sorted out "in no time at all".Truly a classic worth watching time and again if you find yerself feelin blue and missing thoughts of days gone by in happier times when the sun is shining most lovely on fields that seem always green and the troubles at present be too much for 'ye.Enjoy!

reviews.review_title: John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara at their best
reviews.content: A marvelous romantic comedy set in Ireland.  The scenery is beautiful; the story line unusual; the players magnificent.  This movie is a delightful treat that needs to be experienced.  And once you've seen it, you will treasure it for life.  Get the DVD version so you can pass it on to your grandchildren.

reviews.review_title: This is the enjoyable, wholesome kind of movie that they don't seem to make anymore today.
reviews.content: An excellent John Ford Film set in Ireland. Sean Thorton (John Wayne) returns from America to his native town and is immediately taken by the feisty Irish lass, Mary Kate (Maureen O'Hara). I knew I was going to like this movie from the opening scene when Sean gets off the train and asks for directions. A nice blend of comedy, drama, and romance...and the beautiful Irish countryside. Of course there is a bit of conflict between Sean and her brother which prohibits her from following her heart due to strict courting rules. The town match-maker helps to fix things up though...at least temporarily. Unfortunately Sean doesn't want to fight the brother due to a bad experience he had in the boxing ring. But of course it turns out he is willing to fight for one thing, the respect of his wife. This is the enjoyable, wholesome kind of movie that they don't seem to make anymore today.***1/2 (out of 4)

reviews.review_title: A poorly paced and twee first half and a stronger and slightly more focused second half results in The Quiet Man being an uneven and rather average offering
reviews.content: Sean Thornton (John Wayne) returns back to the village where he was born in Ireland after moving across to America when he was young where he forged a career as a boxer. Now retired, he plans on buying back his former family home whilst also falling for fiery Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara). However, Kate's brother Will Danaher (Victor McLaglen) doesn't approve of their relationship and makes things rather difficult for the couple. Meanwhile, Thornton is also hiding a dark secret from his past as well...The first hour of The Quiet Man (in my humble opinion) is where the film is at its weakest; not a great deal happens and character development is rather poor. I can possibly see that revealing little about Thornton until right near the end may have worked for some people - perhaps they may have been intrigued by him. However, I myself found it rather tedious and in order to enjoy a film I need to be able to form some kind of emotional investment in the characters or the story and for the first hour or so I was simply unable to do this. It's all just a little bit too quaint, twee and cutesy for my liking. A lot of the songs are pretty bad (with one song being repeated again about 5 minutes after it was originally sung for some reason).Thankfully, it does improve slightly in the second half (when Thornton's dark secret is revealed). It was at this point that I became more involved with the film because I was finally given a better understanding of our protagonist, but I do think that it was a bad move just shoving this reveal on towards the end of the film - it strikes of laziness and I do feel that Thornton should have been given more development and depth earlier in the film which may have made it a more enticing character study. The reveal explains that Thornton killed his opponent during a boxing match which caused him to hang up his gloves for good and he vows never to fight again yet later in the film he contradicts himself and fights Denahar to prove to Mary that he isn't a coward?? To go from Thornton pouring his heart out to a priest about vowing to never fight again only then to start brawling with Denahar seemed a little strange - this is made worse by the fight being totally unnecessary and being given a rather comical spin (both men have water thrown in their faces on several occasions and they even stop for a beer at one point halfway through their fight). It's also made worse by the fact that Thornton seems unfazed by the prospect of knocking seven bells out of Danaher (Thornton has an emotional flashback when he gets knocked to the ground, but for some reasons this never happens on the numerous occasions when he knocks Denahar to the ground??). Despite this final fight being entertaining, narratively it went against pretty much everything that proceeded it.Still it isn't completely irredeemable; the likes of Flynn, McLagen & Fitzgerald all play their parts in making this film as good as they can. Wayne has his usual swagger about him, but he isn't great here and his performance here feels rather artificial - he delivers his lines very slowly and seems to pause for about 5 seconds after delivering about 5 words. There are some funny moments in the film (although Fitzgerald is responsible for most of these).The Quiet Man may have worked better when it was released and was probably heavily reliant on John Wayne's star power, but I found large parts of the film to be uninvolving and despite the second half being quite entertaining it also seemed to give out mixed messages. Average and watchable, but that's about it.

reviews.review_title: A Magnificent Movie That Ages Like Fine Wine
reviews.content: I'm glad that John Wayne got a chance to do "The Quiet Man" during his career.  It proved to everyone that he could actually act without having a six-gun and a horse.  (Okay, he still has the horse, but it's still not a Western.)Set in an indistinct period in rural Ireland, this movie is what movie making is all about... it's entertaining, funny, moving, and it let's you experience something you would likely never see without the help of film.John Wayne plays "Trooper" Thorne, a retired American prize-fighter come home to the "wee humble cottage" where he was born.  He's returned to escape the memories of the tragic event which made him quit the ring, and Wayne does it better than ever.  Maureen O'Hara is absolutely perfect in her portrayal of the Irish "spinster" sister of the town's squire.  The supporting cast is priceless, and if you never get a chance to see Barry Fitzgerald in any other movie, watch him in this one... he's the epitome of everything you could hope for in a fine Irish character actor, and gets more mileage from one dram of blarney than a regiment of lesser actors.I won't give away the story if you've been unfortunate enough to never see this absolute jewel of a film.  For those who have seen it, you already understand.  For those of you who have not, no words can tell you... you need to see it yourself.  Just do it.  Go out to the video rental and track down a copy in the Classics section.  You'll never regret it.This is without a doubt one of my favorite movies of all time... a gem... a jewel... a priceless piece of art.

This is a classic film by the renowned director John Ford, the man who single-handedly defined the Western genre. It stars some gorgeous photography of picturesque Irish locations in eye-popping color, a notable first in Hollywood history. It also stars John Wayne in an atypical role as a retired American boxer who returns to his ancestral homeland, and comes out of retirement so he can beat up a young local woman and her elderly brother.At first it looks like it's going to be a Hollywood romance spiced with local color. John Ford favorites Victor McLaglen and Ward Bond reprise the broad Irish accents they used throughout Ford's cavalry films, and the other Irish locals spend most of their time in the village pub, singing and fighting in true stereotypical Irish fashion. Maureen O'Hara plays a young woman with a fiery Irish temper who falls for the Duke.But then it gets confusing. O'Hara's character is less feisty and hot-tempered, and more hysterical and psychotic. The romance involves Wayne repeatedly chasing O'Hara, grabbing her, and roughly having his way with her. The climax begins with Wayne dragging her bodily across half the country, and then fighting Victor McLaglen for about an hour and a half.Perhaps this is what passed for romantic comedy in 1952, which just proves that societal progress is a good thing. The casual sexual violence in the film is shocking, confusing, and just plain weird. By about halfway through the film I honestly had no idea why or how the romance between the two leads was still going. On a second viewing, it might become clear that the real relationship we're meant to care about is the brawny homoeroticism shared between Wayne and McLaglen.

It would be churlish to say anything negative about such a proved crowd-pleaser as this. Okay, it's totally unrealistic that someone as gorgeous as Maureen O'Hara wouldn't have suitors coming from miles around and would be so totally available even if this is a low-rent version of The Taming Of The Shrew but we can look the other way for a couple of hours and bask in the feel-good elements that range from the scenery to the Central Casting 'Irish Whimsy' types that run through the film like 'Blackpool' through a stick of rock. The surprise is that a movie like this was made by Poverty Row's Republic but apparently the majors turned down Ford's pitch flat. The hokey element of the boxer who killed a man in the ring and is reluctant to fight again has also been done to death (ouch) but again we're happy to overlook it - though even as the film was in release James Jones was using the same cliché in his best-selling novel From Here To Eternity when the character in question, Robert E Lee Prewit, merely blinded an opponent. These cavils aside this is a great enjoyable romp and the only jarring note was the faded color on the print screened today by Film 4.

One of the best paced movies ever made. Also gloriously entertaining, with bigger than life performances, direction, and cinematography. The Quiet Man isn't intended to be a realistic film, it is an entertainment with characters drawn from John Ford's memories of his childhood. It may not appeal to people who want the milquetoast version of leading men and women now extant. This movie has STARS and is hugely wonderfully lavish and fun. One of my all-time favorites.
Enthusiastically portrays abuse towards women like it's the way life's supposed to be and that women enjoy being abused.

A former boxer (John Wayne) returns to his birthplace in the genteel Irish village of Inisfree in John Ford's paean to his Irish heritage. Filmed in lush Technicolor, Ford's compositions are as redoubtable here as they were in How Green Was My Valley, which used a colliery as the point-of-focus in myriad long, deep-focus shots. Wayne is Sean Thornton, an expatriate American with uncertain difficulty in his past. He falls for Maureen O'Hara, and their courtship yields some of the most sensuous moments I've seen on film: Taking refuge from the rain in a graveyard, with their shirts soaked through, their embraces feel tactile and combustible 50 years later. It's a seductive affair that seems to belong as much to the young lovers as to Ford himself, his generous telling and detailing of people and events inviting us to fall in love, fully immersed temporally and spatially. I think more than anything else, this is what Ford seems to desire in his mise-en-scene and preference for long shots that surround his characters in inviting settings. He is a born storyteller, fascinated by the people who compose an ethnography, in their ways of relating to and coping with their chosen lives. The film also contains a satisfying collection of supporting characters who retain defining quirks and specific agencies. It all adds up to a highly idealized tribute to the resiliency and self-sufficiency of the Irish people, who live in pastoral bliss, where jails are obsolete because all grievances can be worked out with a good donnybrook. Its resonant message, that fighting for what one desires or believes in can redeem even the most hopeless of cases, is direct, sound, and refreshingly rewarding of virtuous intentions.

reviews.review_title: "He'll regret it till his dying day . . . "
reviews.content: " . . . if he ever lives that long," Victor McLaglen's "Red Will" says of John Wayne's "Sean Thornton" early on in John Ford's THE QUIET MAN. Few truer words were ever said, and they could apply to pretty much all the American cast and crew with whom McLaglen was hanging out. Though the UNHOLY THREE is the title of a Silent Classic, it's hard to think of a more apt umbrella to cover QUIET director Ford, star Wayne, and narrator Ward Bond. Few Americans have hurt more of their fellow citizens with Racist and Anti-Semitic outbursts. One of these men was involved with the mendacious Silent BIRTH OF A NATION. Another was on the Racists-Will-Rise-Again GONE WITH THE WIND payroll. The third led the Kill-the-Jews (often literally, as with John Garfield) Hollywood Witch Hunts immediately after World War Two (while enlisting the help of the first two for his pogrom). Eva Braun found out that History judged her by the company she kept. Watching THE QUIET MAN, one is torn between pity and contempt for its female lead, Maureen O'Hara. Of course, Bobby Darin sang that Mack the Knife could be as charming as he needed to be. But when you frolic and splash around in a blood-filled swimming pool, your judgment is open to question.

reviews.review_title: Magnificent lyrical and romantic ode to the old sod
reviews.content: Everything is magnificent in this classic (in every sense of the word) masterpiece.  The cinematography, the dialogue, the interplay, every last detail is perfect.  But, the chemistry between Maureen O'Hara and John Wayne is totally electric.  (I was so disappointed when Casablanca was pitched to me as a romance because the chemistry between Bogart and Bergman was forced and more-or-less non-existent.  See Bogie in To Have and Have Not or Key Largo to see how he can effect romantic chemistry.)  So when the romantic chemistry was pitched to me for this John Wayne movie, I said "Sure, right." And that's what most of my friends say before I get them to watch it.  But once watched, everyone appreciates it for what it is, one of the most romantic movies of all time in all the best meanings of the word "romantic." Since then I watched Wayne in Angel and the Badman and Wake of the Red Witch, two in which he also quite good, but nothing touches the Quiet Man. 11/10.

reviews.review_title: John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara make a movie great!
reviews.content: One of the best films. Lots of action. Maureen O'Hara in a part she plays well. Fiery Irish colleen Maureen O'Hara, redhair and a temper to match. Strong willed and set on having what is hers at the expense of anything else. Her brother harsh and strong willed giving Maureen a bad time, tempers flare and there begins huge fights between sister and brother. Along comes Sean Thorton a prizefighter from America. Played by John Wayne, come home to buy the cottage where he was born and retire. Barry Fitzgerald the town matchmaker. Delightful,sometimes funny, excitement, great fight scenes, as John Wayne goes after a beauty Maureen O'Hara. Colorful scenery and country shots filmed in techicolor, even a horse race. Maureen and John give the movie romance that one won't forget. I liked this film. Seeing them fall in love, but also see the strength in the character that John Wayne displayed to hold on to Maureen a very strong willed girl.
