At times you will find yourself laughing as the tempers flare and none willing to give up their position for the other. Enjoy this Irish tale. It is wonderfully entertaining

reviews.review_title: A timeless film with many long-time and well-known actors
reviews.content: When he wasn't riding through Monument Valley, in a shootout with desperados, or involved in fisticuffs in a Western movie, John Wayne was known to have acted in an occasional film of another genre. He made some very good adventure and action films -- "Hellfighters" of 1968, "Harari" of 1962, and "Blood Alley" of 1955. He was in some memorable war films - "Back to Bataan" of 1945, "The Longest Day" of 1962, and "Cast a Giant Shadow" of 1966. And he could act very well in comedies and romances -- "Without Reservations" of 1946, "North to Alaska" of 1960, and "Donovan 's Reef" of 1963.""The Quiet Man" is one of Wayne's best non-Westerns. It's a very good comedy romance and drama, with an excellent plot and superb screenplay. And, what's really interesting about the making of this film is that John Ford directs it and it includes some others of the unoxfficial "stock" and frequent cast members from Ford's Westerns. So, Ward Bond, Victor McLaglen and Maureen O'Hara all have co-starring roles. Toss in Barry Fitzgerald, and the touches of comedy are polished off nicely.Few people know why American Sean Thornton has moved to the small Irish town to buy and live in the home where he was born. And, when John Wayne's Thornton spots Maureen O'Hara's Mary Kate Danaher herding sheep, he feels a new lease on life. But he may have trouble courting her when he acquires his property. Mary Kate's brother, Squire Will Danaher, had been after that property for a long time. McLaglen's Danaher may forever prevent Sean and Mary Kate being united. Ah, but marriage may still be possible due to the interest and efforts of Bond's Father Peter Lonergan and the town's senior match-maker, Fitzgerald's Michaeleenn Flynn.The Quiet Man was a highly popular film in 1952. If finished the year in 10th place at the box office and won two Oscars with five more nominations, including Best Picture. It's probably the best film that the lesser studio, Republic, made in its 33 years from 1935-1967.This is a most enjoyable film with a plot and setting that is timeless. Audiences of all ages should be able to enjoy it yet well into the future. Here are some favorite lines from the film.Sean Thornton, on first seeing Mary Kate Danaher in the distance, "Hey, is that real? She couldn't be." Michaleen Flynn, "Ah, nonsense, man. It's only a mirage brought on by your terrible thirst."Squire "Red" Will Danaher, "He'll regret it to his dying day, if ever he lives that long."Michaleen Flynn, "Heh, heh. You're a well-propertied woman. I wouldn't mind marrying ye myself."Michaleen Flynn, "Easy now! Easy now! This is a courtin', not a donnybrook. Have the good manners not to hit the man 'til he's your husband, and until he can hit you back."

reviews.review_title: Visually great, good performances but story doesn't hold up
reviews.content:
The cinematography of this film, filmed on location in Ireland, is stunning.
The actors are in solid form but there are a number of problems with this story which have only grown worse with modern times.
Without giving things away let's start out with O'Hara, who is initially presented as a tough as nails hard headed Irish woman but Ford slowly knocks her down and the more he does the less the character is believable. Reading today about how Ford obsessed over her it seems he may have been trying to abuse her on screen in a way he couldn't off screen.
A lot of the scenes just do not make much sense and the more this story goes on the more one gets the feeling that Ford was a little punch drunk making this. When reading about this today we have been told by ohara that Ford was quite a bad drunk during the filming which makes a lot of sense. Another smaller problem is that for a story like this the female lead should probably be about 10 years younger. Wayne is 45 here but he is passable because he was always in such good shape.
Barry Fitzgerald is the real star here. Victor mclaglen is also solid but unfortunately he is made to be way too one dimensional and that is one of the greatest faults of the film. Keep your eye out for an assortment of great silent film actors who show up here.
Some modern viewers may consider this a chauvinistic film even if it is set in an earlier time (late 1890s it feels like).
Can't overemphasize how great some of the shots are.

This godawful movie should have been named "Phony Macho Man Kicks Butt."Let me note first that Wayne smokes constantly, which isn't anywhere near the worst thing about the movie, but it sure dates it. Plus every time he lit up I was reminded that he died of lung cancer.What was truly awful was the way Wayne's character abused his woman, and how this was portrayed as the way a real man teaches his woman how to behave. He french kissed her before they were even introduced. He kicked her in the butt, he dragged her against her will for five miles to her brother so he could demand her dowry. (That's called kidnapping, by the way, and is a felony in every jurisdiction I'm familiar with.) He forced her to jump over boxes, he refused to stop when she lost her shoe, he kept going after she fell, dragging her as she lay prone. With a large crowd of villagers cheering him on, by the way, since she obviously deserved to be treated like a rag doll. One of the villagers retrieved her shoe and after a long chase finally caught up with Wayne and his captive. The result of this abuse? She now stood by her man, suitably chastened, lesson learned.Then there was the "fight" between Wayne's character and his brother-in-law. I lost count of the times Wayne's character (a former professional boxer) was sucker punched by the brother-in-law while he wasn't paying attention. The fight proceeded for several miles (OK, that's a slight exaggeration), with all the villagers following. At some point, the fight developed into a melee in which everyone fought everyone. Until Wayne's buddy fired a pistol twice, which immediately calmed everyone down except for our two original protagonists, giving the brother-in-law one more chance to sucker punch Wayne. Even the priests and the cops cheered them on as they fought.And then Wayne's character and his bro-in-law became good friends, and macho man and his now obedient wife were able to finally consummate their marriage and live happily ever after.Compounding Wayne's offensive "macho man" persona is the fact that he was a draft dodger in WWII, staying home to make money instead of trying to contribute to the war effort as virtually all of his contemporaries did. It was not for nothing that.he was booed off the stage by wounded Marines at a naval hospital in Hawaii. Marine veteran William Manchester was there. He described what happened when Wayne made his appearance: "He was greeted by a stony silence. Then somebody booed. Suddenly everyone was booing. This man was a symbol of the fake machismo we had come to hate, and we weren't going to listen to him. He tried and tried to make himself heard, but we drowned him out, and eventually he quit and left."

reviews.review_title: Alas, Wayne finds his match, a virtuous leading lady who can both physically and characteristically challenge him in a Ford picture
reviews.content: John Ford swooped his historically fourth BEST DIRECTOR win for THE QUIET MAN in the Oscars, a record very much likely will never be matched, to say nothing of being surpassed. But it was his only win from a Ford-Wayne picture, THE SEARCHERS (1956) was wholesomely snubbed, but it is not a conventional Ford-Wayne picture either, its locale is deviant from their usual Western landscape.Wayne plays Sean Thornton, an Irish-born American from Pittsburgh, returns to his homeland, a backwater town called Inisfree (a fictional place) in the 1920s, he reclaims his family land from widow Sarah Tillane (Natwick) and falls for an ardent ginger Mary-Kate Danaher (O'Hara), after locking horns with her eldest brother Squire Will Danaher (McLaglen), a loutish heavy who also sets his eyes on Thornton's farm, and according to the provincial tradition, Mary-Kate cannot marry without Squire's consent.With a little conspiracy from Sean's new local friends - yes, Sean is the new apple of the eye for this jerkwater town, who can easily gain trust and favour from denizens over the unwelcome Squire himself. - including the matchmaker Michaeleen Flynn (Fitzgerald), reverend Cyril Playfair's (Shields) and his wife (Crowe), who fabricate a quid pro quo to inveigle Squire to marry Mary-Kate to Sean, so himself in return could marry Ms. Tillane, and the plan works (for the first half), Sean and Mary-Kate ties the knot, but an unknowing Ms. Tillane refuses to take Squire for the team, after a bout of ruckus, Squire holds back Mary-Kate's dowry, which according to Sean's noble confession, doesn't mean anything to him, what he loves is her, not her fortune, but talking about different values, for Mary-Kate, her dowry is not just money, it is her own reputation at stake, that's something worth her husband to fight for, but Sean seems to be unmotivated.Sean's past in USA has been carefully veiled in the narrative, only his burly figure and the occasional attention from reverend Playfair, who is a fervent sport fan, knowingly suggest his vocation, a former prizefighter, who has sworn to abnegate boxing after accidentally knocking off an opponent during a match. Now, coerced by an obdurate Mary-Kate, Sean has to use his fists to earn back her respect and prove that he is not a coward, even though in his mind, it is plumb purposeless, but the point is, that's what husbands must do to defend his womenfolk, so a long- delayed close-range brawl between Sean and Squire arrives ebulliently with on-lookers betting their money on who is the last man standing.THE QUIET MAN adheres to the conventional criteria of a patriarchal society under the microcosm of Inisfree, machismo reeks of booze, smoke, gambles and sweat after a fist fight, even Mary-Kate, a perfect specimen of a fine lady, blindly hamstrings her pride in the shibboleth, which leaves the picture a smack outmoded in the eyes of a new viewer six decades later.Visually expansive, thanks to the sublime topography of the Irish countryside (in the sunny days only) and John Ford's discerning sense of aesthetics, THE QUIET MAN also elicits a more layered performance from John Wayne, not merely a macho bigot bogged in his own intransigence, he can also be a rose-loving, violence-relinquishing pacifist, paired with a strikingly zealous Ms. O'Hara, who is so ambidextrous both indoor and outdoor, whether she is playing harpsichord or playing rough against Wayne. Slas, Wayne finds his match, a virtuous leading lady who can both physically and characteristically challenge him in a Ford picture.Victor McLaglen, who is visibly too old to play big brother of O'Hara (34 years of her senior), is the only member in the cast rewarded with an Oscar nomination, but in retrospect, he chews the scenery a bit little. Yet, it is Barry Fitzgerald who almost single-handedly holds intact the film's comedic vibe as the booze-dependent Flynn, with gusto and impeccable foibles, and in truth, THE QUIET MAN aims to be a bubbly ethnographic study sending a more liberal message - there is no reason why Catholicism and Protestantism cannot co-exist harmoniously under the same roof, maybe not all roads can lead to Rome, but at least there are several of them can. A final nod to Victor Young's majestic score, utterly pertinent to accompany a jolly journey in that bygone era and faraway place.

reviews.review_title: Truly brilliant in both colour and story
reviews.content: There are not a lot of John Wayne fans in the world today, and that is a crying shame. It is my belief that if the nay-sayers of the world would give this film an honest viewing it would quickly change their minds. In this film Wayne plays not the angry cowboy who is quick with his iron, but instead plays a quiet retired man trying to make a peaceful life for himself in his mothers county in Ireland.This film shows the brilliance, of not only Wayne in choosing roles that could show his versatility, but also John Ford and his choices for location, colour, actors and story and how he weaves them together in a film that is sweeping in both its scope and its emotional grounds. I highly recommend this film to those who are fans of John Wayne and Ireland, or those that are discovering them for the first time.

reviews.review_title: Don't have to be Irish to love it.
reviews.content: My Italian father introduced me to "The Quiet Man" in the 1950's and I've been a fan ever since. It was the first movie I owned on VHS. It's a beautifully entertaining (and beautifully filmed) picture that has a sub plot to please everyone: romance, comedy, drama, and one of the best fight scenes of all time. It sits at the top of my 10 best list, just above "Citizen Kane."

John Ford's love letter to old Ireland is romanticised, sentimental and almost completely disregarding of the parlous political state of the country at the supposed time of its making and it stars John Wayne, but still I can't resist its many charms. It also features throughout a thoroughly chauvinistic and subservient treatment of women that you wouldn't see today and still it effortlessly wins me over.It does so with its enchanting depiction of the Irish countryside, a vivacious soundtrack which seems of itself to drive the film along and a cast who, to a man and woman, commit themselves completely to the story and their characters and seem to have great fun in so doing. Once you park all that outmoded "Woman, where's me tea?" caveman-like nonsense and surrender to the wonderful flow of the picture, it's obvious that the movie is made with tender love and care. Ford had wanted to make this film for years and considered it his favourite and it shows in every frame and while some of the director's cliched characterisation and bawdy humour might occasionally make you wince, its big heart will win you over.The big lunk Wayne carries the action with his familiar swagger and not unexpectedly in a Ford movie finds himself surrounded by familiar faces hamming it up in the old country, like Victor McLagen as the flinty Danaher, Barry Fitzgerald as the leprechaun-like Flynn and Ward Bond as the fight-loving reverend father while O'Sullivan is terrific as the bartered and after Thornton fetches her from the station, battered bride.With its mix of sly risqué humour and broader comedy and despite being politically incorrect throughout, "The Quiet Man" is a knockout pretty much from the first bell to the last.To be sure...

reviews.review_title: A good classic, but it didn't really capture me
reviews.content: I heard a little bit of The Quiet Man, mostly from my film books, how it was one of the greatest movies of all time. Now this sounds crazy, after all the movies I have seen, I never thought of it, but I never saw a movie with John Wayne. One of the most famous icons of our time, how could I not know at least one of his films? Now despite the fact that it may not be a "John Wayne" film, no western action, Irish in fact, but I didn't mind. While I would agree that this movie is a classic in itself, I didn't really get into it. It was pretty clichéd, but I think this was the film that made clichés before there was any type of movie cliché, so that's not my complaint. The story just really didn't get to me like I thought it would.Sean moves to his home land of Ireland from America, he has a life he would like to settle down too. His eyes are captured by a young but fiesty Mary Kate who becomes betrothed to him, but her brother Will won't have of it since he has a bad feeling of Sean's past and presence. Mary Kate grows to love Sean, but loves her brother and wants his blessing with their marriage, but Will is definitely going to give them a hard time before he does that.It has action and romance, not to mention a great and strong cast that worked very well together. I would recommend this film for any classic film lovers, it's one to check out. It just didn't keep my interest, but I would never deny in a million years that it was a good movie. John Wayne is a terrific actor and really kept the film going with Maureen, they had good chemistry, loved how they had their first kissing scene with the dramatic wind, always a crowd pleaser.7/10
The AFI should be ashamed of itself for not including this delightful movie in its top-100.  PULP FICTION but not THE QUIET MAN?  Yeah, right!

This movie was recommended to me by my relatives. And there is much to recommend it: Maureen O ' Hara's brother writing down people's names if they did something he did not like (is this an older version of kicking someone's butt and taking their name?); the courting rituals were great - takes me back to a time before even me - made me even more aware of our hedonistic society where people are mating like dogs in heat - 75% of their children out of wedlock; John Wayne trying to take control of his wedding night & failing; and John Wayne dragging Maureen O' Hara home for miles (he'd be in jail today for that kind of treatment.)But the fight scene is the classic moment - John & the brother fought seemingly from Innisfree to Dublin! This fell short of Rowdy Roddy Piper and Keith David in They LIve, but it was humorous - still not bad for 1952. I was wondering why I missed this film - but then I was only 4 years old & my parents would not have let me see such violence - well, actually they would have.I guess my enduring thought as I watched this classic was: What would Quentin have done with this picture? Sorry for the sacrilege, Auntie.

What starts out as being mildly interesting, amusing and entertaining spirals into a bizarre story of wife abuse and abuse of women in general. This movie is an insult to all women and it has absolutely no other purpose. Unlike GWTW, which actually shows a woman, despite the limitations of the day, strongly pursuing her goals, whether they be food, money or men, "The Quiet Man" reveals Maureen O'Hara ("Mary Kate"), certainly one of the most beautiful women of her generation, as someone who has no future unless a man marries her. She is a slave to her obnoxious older brother "Red" (Victor McLaglen), but once John Wayne ("Sean") looks at her, she belongs to him and him only.The problem is, though, Mary Kate has a temper (gee, I wonder why, since her entire life is lived in service of obnoxious men who never once acknowledge her breathtaking beauty -- okay, Sean says she looks pretty one time; wow, good on him, that must have been a real stretch) or her skills as a pianist or her beautiful singing voice. She is a cook, a maid, a sister and/or a wife; she can be nothing else. So, no wonder she is angry and has a temper. And of course, because she has a temper, she must be harnessed, and beaten and controlled. It's horrific.In what realm of the imagination could anyone call this a "masterpiece"???This horrid, horrid film tells us (literally spells it out in newsprint, underlined, in case we're too thick to get it) that Sean, a "Yank," accidentally killed a man in a boxing match in America, but because his parents were Irish, he has come home to claim the house they grew up in. How he makes money, how he intends to make money, is never explained. But when he meets Mary Kate (and decides within nanoseconds that he's going to make her his own), she actually has money of her own, her dowry. But Sean doesn't want it; money is problematic (why? Inexplicable, since we don't know where he's getting his). So, a good portion of the film is about how Mary Kate, even though she marries Sean, refuses to be his wife (meaning sleep with him) unless she can have her dowry, which Red refuses to let go of. (This however does not stop Sean from cruelly and viciously throwing Mary Kate into the wedding bed so hard that she falls off it and the bed breaks.)This "problem" leads to an endless, insane, poorly choreographed, laughable, pathetic "fight sequence" between Red and Sean, which involves the entire town, who swarm around Red and Sean like rabid fans.This "fight sequence" also involves Sean having to track down Mary Kate, who has decided that she "loves him too much," and so must leave him. Once Sean finds her, he forces her back to Red's house (this is the most horrible part; he drags her, kicks her, pulls her, shoves her -- all accompanied by cutesy "Irish" music), then, once he gets to Red's house, "delivers" her back to Red by hurling her at Red's feet.Then there is further insanity about Mary Kate's dowery, which Red finally gives to Sean (it's all coins) by throwing it at him and Mary Kate. Mary Kate attempts to gather her dowry (which has taken her a lifetime to attain), but Sean won't have any of it, and takes all of it and tosses it in to a burning stove. This is how he "conquers" her and "wins" her back -- after which the fight sequence proper begins and we are treated to what seems like an hour-long sequence of utter madness, all accompanied by toe-tapping, back-clapping "Irish" music.At the end of the film, everyone is where they are supposed to be, and they all stand, frozen, as if posing for a Daguerrotype, as the camera pans across their faces, and we finish our little "play" in the Irish country side.It is horrid, horrible, unwatchable, unbearable, insulting, degrading, and unforgivable. Yes, there is some pretty Irish countryside, but no matter how much beauty we are treated to, it's clear that John Wayne can't act, Maureen O'Hara was treated like garbage and apparently didn't know that she had a voice and could speak up for herself, that Barry Fitzgerald's tragically alcoholic second banana wasn't funny for one second, and that women were not only second class citizens -- they had less rights than farm animals.I do not know how this could have garnered any Oscars, but other than being used in a university course entitled, "How Hollywood abused its female stars" or "Toxic Masculinity and the studio system that supported it" -- I do not see any remote cultural value in this movie.Left a bad taste in my mouth and really made me feel bad for Maureen O'Hara, who clearly had talent and world class beauty and deserved so, so, so much better.

Hopefully younger generations will have the opportunity to experience this classic John Ford creation. Rarely do we have the opportunity to witness such a deeply warm and vulnerable side of the Duke. Old Ire traditions are respectfully molded into this wonderful tale of an American's return to his family's roots while fleeing from his past. Maureen O'Hara is just stunning. This DVD will remain in my collection, only to gladly be passed on to our children and their children. A masterpiece from generations past that seems to adjust very well to our current times also. As much of a fan of the crusty old Duke's hardness as I'll always be, this depiction of the completely opposite side of him is my absolute fave.

This is one of John Wayne's best films. Of course, it is always interesting to see him in a film that's not set in the American west or on a battlefield.John Ford has directed a finely-crafted, joyful film about an American who travels to Ireland in search of paradise and finds a beautiful woman with an independent spirit, Wayne plays Sean Thornton, a man with a secret, who must adjust to Irish ways and contend with the cantankerous brother (Victor McLaglen) of the woman (Maureen O'Hara) he wishes to court.The production is marked by beautiful scenery, wonderful dialogue, and a supporting cast that feels authentic to the setting. Though the story revolves around a romance, this is first and foremost a comedy. And it's a broad comedy of pratfalls and innuendos, but somehow it is a gentle story, which probably explains in large part why it's a favorite of so many movie fans.

This is my favourite John Wayne film and I think it's his best. Both him and Maureen O'Hara sizzle as they struggle to be together. I have to say I love Maureen O'Hara's red hair in this film! The only downside sometimes is apart of the scenes shot in the studio with the painted backdrop is that some of the Irish cast are not audible! This film could never be made now because of it's sexual discrimination towards women and condoning that you could beat your wife!

I have always felt a strange mystical connection to Ireland that I've never quite been able to explain and have often dreamed about Connemara, a place I have never visited. Even when I was a boy, my favorite songs were not those on the Hit Parade but ballads such as Danny Boy (okay, it's not Irish), and the more obscure Eileen, Tumble Down Shack in Athlone, and Rose of Arranmore. Given that connection, it is odd that I never saw John Ford's The Quiet Man until this week, perhaps because I thought John Wayne was a wooden and unconvincing actor and did not think that the film would bring me any closer to the Ireland of my dreams.Based on Frank Nugent's adaptation of Maurice Walsh's Saturday Evening Post 1933 short story Green Rushes, The Quiet Man was produced by Republic Pictures, not a major studio at the time but the only one willing to take a chance on a film about the Irish. They were well rewarded with a film that won Academy Awards for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Cinematography as well as four other nominations. Wayne plays Sean Thornton, a boxer from Pittsburgh who gave up the ring after he accidentally killed a man in a fight. The ex-prize fighter returns to Innisfree to buy the Irish cottage in which he was born and sets his eyes on Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara), a redhead with an infamous temper.Mary Kate's older brother, 'Red' Will Danaher (Victor McLagen), a town bully refuses to consent to his sister's marriage and it is left to alcoholic Matchmaker Michaleen Flynn (Barry Fitzgerald) and the local pastor Father Lonergan (Ward Bond) to trick Danaher into changing his mind. When brother Will realizes he's been tricked, however, he refuses to pay the dowry that includes family treasures, furniture, and 350 gold coins and Mary Kate refuses to consummate the marriage. This leads to an inevitable confrontation with Thornton and a barroom brawl that clocks in at nine minutes.Though partly filmed in Ireland with scenery that is verdant and beautiful, The Quiet Man has an artificial quality to it that all the Barry Fitzgerald colloquialisms do not change. Though it was a personal favorite of Ford and is all in good fun, it is an overly romanticized film complete with Hollywood stars, quaint Irish brogues, horses and carts, and balladeers ready to burst into song at every tavern. The brogues, however, are not the only quaint items in the film. There is also the macho attitude that makes it imperative that a man has to physically confront a bully regardless of the odds.It also brings the audience to applause as they watch a man drag and kick his wife five miles by her hair, then receive a stick by a villager with which to "beat yer lovely wife with". I realize the scene is played for laughs and maybe Mary Kate deserved such treatment for her materialistic obsessions, but it still resonates poorly with this twenty-first century viewer. I think those with a strong feeling for Ireland would be better off avoiding the blarney of The Quiet Man and reading James Joyce, William Butler Yeats, or simply listening to the exquisite Danny Boy, a song that never fails to bring tears to my eyes.

reviews.review_title: The Most Wonderful Movie Ever Made!!!
reviews.content: What A Classic! Never has celluloid been used for so noble a purpose as to put John Ford's Classic together with an assembly of such luminaries as John Wayne, Barry Fitzgerald, and the beautiful Maureen O'Hara!As Sean Thornton (John Wayne) finds his Irish roots, he stumbles across the town spinster Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara). He soon aims to swoon her when he employs Michaleen Flynn (Barry Fitzgerald), the town busy body, and certified match maker. An uprorious dramatic climax peaks when Sean Thornton and Ms Danaher's brother Squire 'Red' Will Danaher (Victor McLaglen) finally come to punches.Watch for some cameo's by Mr. Wayne's son & daughter, as well as John Ford's brother. An assembly of stars never to gather again in the Hollywood constellations.

If ever there was a coming together of personalities that was more perfect than here in The Quiet Man, I would be surprised.John Wayne, the American icon, John Ford a film making visionary, Maureen O'Hara, beautiful and strong enough to match both of the aforementioned men.The supporting play from all concerned was peerless.One of the best films ever made.PS. Why did Maureen O'Hara never win an Oscar?

I've just come back from seeing this film at the movies, and I had a heated discussion with my friends about it. I have to say that I found it really dated and offensive towards women. It's not only the fact that violence generally and specifically against women is glorified. I just couldn't stand the fact that the woman was expecting her husband to be violent against her. She doesn't respect him and thinks he's a coward until he finally gets all macho and treats her really rough, which is greeted by applause and cheers from the whole village. My friend argued that this was just how things were those days, but I think it's one thing to show how things are in society, and another to take a quite dubious custom and transform it into supposedly light entertainment. Although this was my main complaint about the movie, there were other aspects I didn't like: This seems to be more an American fantasy of idyllic Ireland than a remotely realistic portrait, and most of the actors do not even have an Irish accent, as far as I can judge. John Wayne's acting is quite bad, and the film is much too long for my taste. I liked the beautiful landscape though, and Maureen O'Hara is absolutely stunning. Also there were some funny moments that made me chuckle.

This film demonstrates all there is to wonderful film making. John Ford, as impossible as it seemed at the time out did himself in this spectacular film. It gives a very accurate description of the times in Ireland and a very accurate description of an American coming to Ireland at that time. The scenery captured in this forever delightful film is history making. The acting by all the cast is unforgettable! Barry Fitzgerald is among many who truly shine in their role in this film. The soundtrack is wonderful as well. The Quiet Man just as well may be summed up as Perfection!

I had never seen this film all the way through, only clips of it in film documentaries, but one afternoon TCM was playing it and I wasn't feeling well, so I snuggled into bed and said to myself: "I am going to sit through this whole movie this time and see what I think." I was glad I did. Never been a big John Wayne fan, but I DID enjoy this film. I was slow to warm to it at first but after the first half hour found myself smiling and laughing at some of the action and dialogue. Maureen O'Hara was a delight and beautiful as always, and John's character was more than one-dimensional, a problem that I find in many of his other films. Perhaps the passion he held for the film project contributed to his fine performance as the American who comes to Ireland to escape his tragic boxing past. I enjoyed all the side characters too and found it pretty realistic of small town life in Ireland, not stereotypical at all. One thing I would like to mention is that I enjoyed the musical soundtrack and the Irish folk songs I heard in the film. I wish someone who knows more about this type of music than I do would list the titles on the IMD someday. I definitely recommend this charming film classic.

reviews.review_title: Simply, the love of the Irish way.
reviews.content: THE QUIET MAN is a film with which everyone can relax. If you are Irish, you might have some objections. I will always remember this movie for luxurious and magical view of the Irish countryside, a very strange romance and long and comical showdown. Despite some moments of the traditional story is bright and cheerful. Nice to see so much of life, colors of sound and noise in a rural idyll. Traditional customs are further spiced up the already intriguing romance. Intimacy is almost non-existent. All the villagers were sent to certain traditional and cultural moments.Looking from the side, these relations act comic, but actually magic. The climax is expected. I'd describe it as one unavoidable ritual into a large family. The atmosphere is positive, good scenery and visual effects have a certain sentimental value.John Wayne as Sean Thornton is a quiet man who turns into a "raging bull" to show love for his wife. I do not want his violent process a custom attribute. In love man often make a craze. This escapade is accidentally expected and justified. Thumbs up for Mr. Wayne. Maureen O'Hara as Mary Kate Danaher is like a flame of fire in her hair. Quickly catch fire, and even faster off. Simply, the love of the Irish way.

The Quiet Man (1952) -It's quite ridiculous that people of their age should need to ask permission and have to be accompanied by a chaperone even at the beginning of the 20th Century.And I think for me, that somewhat skewed my opinion of the film. It's not a romance, it's a fight and while I can see that it was probably done that way to appeal to both the female and male audiences (Predominantly John Wayne fans I would imagine), it hasn't really aged well, especially watching it in a time when everyone is fighting for their rights. It makes things like dowry's and asking permissions seem very inappropriate and outdated.The general script is amusing, especially those lines spoken by Barry Fitzgerald as Michaeleen Flynn, although it doesn't show the Irish population as a very forward thinking people and instead represents them all as heejits who solve things with liquor and their fists.And in the end that is the solution to all of Sean's problems. Treat 'em mean to keep 'em keen! Although he was a bit too rough to my mind. I'm not sure that's what women really want either, but Maureen O'Hara as Kate seems to respect the ex boxer all the more for it.And although the film is a lot of fuss and drama for no real reason that I can see, it is fairly cute.Who can tame the wild and fiery Mary Kate Danaher? Only one man of course, the one who has won all of the wars and defeated all of the villains in the Wild West, John Wayne as Sean Thornton.The sets are a bit dodgy at times and it seems that even Mr Wayne complained about that when the film was made, but other than that it's an enjoyable watch that doesn't require too much thought. Not essentially the type of film that I would normally rush to watch, but I wouldn't be upset if someone asked me to watch it with them. I'd probably be thinking of 'Star Wars' (1977) though.456.66/1000.

The Quiet Man's desire to be subversive is mildly apparent, but it's still retrograde and sexist, propping up these societal gender roles in ways that is difficult to defend outside of considering it tepid satire of European masculinity. Also, Wayne is far too strong a male presence to play this character without seeming abusive; someone like Ford-staple James Stewart would've killed it. Still, the direction is super romantic, and the story is fairly engaging, even if it is tonally scattered.

Having just seen this movie yet again, I can say, without a doubt, that it is one of the best movies ever. The chemistry with Maureen O'Hara and JW is amazing, the the character support is without equal. Just look at McAlleen in his matchmaker role while deep in the sauce ... realistic and endearing. The old standby's from the Ford western epics show their acting chops in the ability to transition, and the entire cast are well prepared for every opportunity. I can personally say that this is a well paced, acted, directed and overall humanistic approach to a set piece that could never be duplicated (and should never be attempted!)A 10 in my book every day!

reviews.review_title: Green, Green It's Green They Say!
reviews.content: "The Quiet Man" was Director John Ford's homage to his homeland Ireland. There's green everywhere as he proudly displays the Irish countryside.The story revolves around Sean Thornton (John Wayne) an ex patriot who has been raised in the USA and returns to his homeland following a tragic occurence in the boxing ring. He is met at the train station by the Michaeleen Flynn (Barry Fitzgerald), which is not explained. He offers to take Thornton to his destination. Along the way, they stop briefly and Thornton catches sight of a beautiful redhead named Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara). Love at first sight? You bet.Thornton learns that his family's old cottage is now owned by the rich widow Sarah Tillane (Mildred Natwick). He goes to her home to buy back his ancestral home. Squire "Red" Will Danaher (Victor McLaglan) and Mary Kate's brother is also there to bid on the property. Danaher has his eye on the widow but she chooses to sell to Thornton which enrages the burly man who takes an immediate dislike to him.Thornton takes possession of the cottage and finds Mate Kate within having been tidying up the place. He grabs hold of her and kisses her only to get that patented O'Hara slap across the face. Thornton decides to go courting but is first faced with the local custom of employing a marriage arranger (Flynn) to keep the parties discretely apart until the wedding. Brother Will fiercely opposes the union.After spending the night at a graveyard during a rain storm, Danaher reluctantly agrees to the wedding but refuses to release Mary Kate's dowry. To Mary Kate, the marriage cannot be consummated until she receives her dowry. In a memorable scene, Thornton breaks down the bedroom door when Mary Kate locks him out and throws her roughly onto the bed breaking it. When Flynn arrives the next morning he thinks that the couple had spent a memorable wedding night. Not so.This arrangement goes on even when Mary Kate gets her furniture from her brother. But Will has withheld the money portion of the dowry. Thornton becomes increasingly frustrated. When Mary Kate in a feeling of guilt leaves to flee to Dublin, Thornton in a rage, goes after her and drags her back to her brother. Up to now, Thornton had been reluctant to fight Danaher due to his past but this time no punches are pulled and......................................................John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara had a marvelous chemistry on screen. It is quite apparent that they really liked each other (professionally of course). This film turned out to be somewhat of a family affair. John Ford employed his brother Francis in the role of the bearded Dan Tobin and his som Patrick worked behind the scenes. Maureen O'Hara's two brothers, Charles Fitzsimmons and James O'Hara had roles in the picture and Barry Fitzgerald and Arthur Shields (who plays the protestant minister) were brothers and John Wayne's four children Michael, Melinda, Patrick and Toni also appear. Ken Curtis appears unbilled as the accordian playing Dermot Fahy.There were a couple of instances of sexual tension displayed in the picture. Ford had to be careful with the censors as this was only 1951. There's plenty of so-called Fordian humor to go around as well. Barry Fitzgerald and Victor McLaglan steal the film in my opinion. Ford, O'Hara and Wayne cited this as their favorite film. It's no coincidence that neither Ford nor Wayne ever worked at Republic Pictures again. They jusy didn't like studio boss Herbert J. Yates constant cost cutting and interferance.Not for everyone, it is nonetheless a classic of its day.

A favorite in my youth, The Quiet Man remains one of my favorite movies of all time. And this is one of John Wayne's best! A well-told story with a great cast, strong characters, and great humor. The men are men and the women are women. Each having their own strengths and flaws. Every character is a character. Visually, intellectually and morally The Quiet Man is a treat. It has none of the gratuitous garbage that more recent films are burdened with, and holds it's own all the more for the difference. The Quiet Man is infinitely suitable for family viewing and can be heartily recommended for the young. A great movie to share with the next generation, particular with the advent of large screen televisions and front projectors. This is a timeless story and will be enjoyed for ages.
This is by far the best movie John Wanye has every done. It shows that he can act in something other than a war movie or a Western. It also has the longest fight scene he has been in.

Like some on the message board, I am not a big John Wayne fan. I am a huge Maureen O'Hara fan. Just so you know the boundaries.I think the chemistry between Wayne and O'Hara is magical. I'll agree that Wayne isn't the great speech maker, but like so many have said, it wasn't his style. I would encourage you to look at the scene where Wayne and O'Hara are trying to find cover from the rain. It looks like they found it, but they just stand there in the rain. What's great about this scene is the whole pace of the movie slows almost to a stop at this point (magnificent direction by John Ford), and O'Hara follows Wayne's lead. It is Wayne who begins to relax first in her physical comfort and then O'Hara follows and turns her head on Wayne's chest. One of the best love scenes I've ever seen played (better without a kiss).You've got to love Barry Fitzgerald, "There'll be no playin paddy fingers in the Holy water..." What a hoot! Maureen O'Hara at her best, and I feel the most vulnerable of all her roles (though some may argue her first with Laughton). I don't think we would have perceived Kate Danaher as vulnerable if it would not have been Wayne playing Sean. Just my opinion. O'Hara always seemed to be playing a losing hand to Wayne even when she was holding out for the dowery. Although a great acting job by Ms. O'Hara did give us some doubts as well they should.Moral of the story: Get Angry, Fight, Make Up, Kiss and drink plenty of Liquid Refreshments.

Hot! Hot! Hot! "The Quiet Man" is the greatest, and John Wayne is quite appealing as the 6'4 1/2" tall newlywed -- what a hunka man... I hate those John Wayne army movies, World War II, Indian fighting, boring guy-movies. But I have discovered that John Wayne could actually be quite a sexy man, and even quite handsome when dressed in civilized clothes that women would like. You can have all his old Army-helmet movies that bore me to tears. There was another one of his "romantic" movies (I don't remember the name, though), where he is on a passenger-or-cruise-ship, totally civilian. Somehow I am remembering that there is a lady involved in this one, too -- perhaps even Maureen O'Hara??? At any rate, score one again for John Wayne the real man. In that movie he is wearing a dark blazer, maybe navy blue, with a white dress shirt underneath. Now, there's the real John Wayne.

Possible SPoiler--Ironically, my favorite Wayne movie, the Quiet Man, features a John Wayne that fires no guns, doesn't put on a cowboy hat the whole movie, and only beats up one person (okay, two if you count the flashback).  best brawl scene in any movie.  One of those great movies set in Ireland that doesn't patronize the Irish culture.  Rather, Wayne and O'Hara captivate the audience.  Wayne surprised me by how laid back and relaxed he seemed playing a much different caricature than usual.  A must see for John Wayne fans.

This is one of the most delightful and effortlessly entertaining film romances. It also might be the ultimate John Ford film, bringing together almost everything that made his films his own in one package. There's Ireland, male bonding, horse racing, and John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara, along with most of his regular supporting cast like Ward Bond and Victor McLaglen. The production was apparently very hard on Ford, to the point where he was bedridden for several days during which Wayne directed some of the horse racing sequence, but the end result is just so completely charming that it's hard to imagine that there could have been that much turmoil involved in the making.Sean Thorton (Wayne) arrives in the small Irish town of Inisfree from America with the aim of purchasing the house in which he was born. His parents moved him to Pittsburg when he was a small child, and the house is owned by the Widow Sarah Tillane (Mildred Natwick). Guided by the local Michaeleen (Barry Fitzgerald), who seems to have no life other than tagging along with Sean, the new arrival appears at the widow's house with cash ready to offer her for the property. The problem is that the Squire Will Danaher (McLaglen) has wanted the land for some time as well, but the widow decides to offer up the land to Sean pretty much to exclusively annoy Danaher. Danaher ends up hating Sean from the start, which wouldn't be a huge issue if Sean wasn't completely smitten with Danaher's spinster, redheaded, and hot-headed sister Mary Kate (O'Hara).Mary Kate has long since given up on marrying (having turned away more than her fair share, convinced they were only after her money), but when the handsome, tall, and somewhat brash American shows up and shows affection for her, she can't do much but fall for him at the same time. The problem ends up being that the custom in Ireland is that, barring a father, a sister must receive permission to marry from her eldest brother, Will.Watching The Quiet Man for the first time in a while, I kept thinking of two other Ford films that I don't like very, Tobacco Road and How Green Was My Valley. The former was a broad comedy that relied heavily on Southern American stereotypes, and the latter was anchored by an opening that made life in the small Welsh mining town seem so saccharinely perfect. The Quiet Man relies on broad Irish stereotypes, and it also builds its story on a heavily idealized version of Ireland. However, I find that the combination ends up working incredibly well in The Quiet Man where it didn't in the earlier films. The stereotypes are gentler and less broad while the picturesque ideal of Ireland is helpfully offset by actual conflict. Yes, Ford's vision of Ireland is too nice, but it's not so nice as to preclude any actual drama from the start. Sean is viewed as an outsider, though he's welcomed, but most importantly, Will acts as an actual dramatic obstacle to overcome from the moment he's introduced.Will doesn't want Sean to have the land, and he doesn't want Sean to have Mary Kate. Something must be done, and Michaeleen concocts a scheme with Father Lonergan (Bond) and a few others to convince Will that the only reason the widow doesn't return his affections is because Will still has an adult woman in the house, his sister. Sean is not in on this plot, but when Sean wins the horse race, snatching up the widow's bonnet instead of Mary Kate's, Will becomes convinced that Sean has given up on Mary Kate and is now pursuing the widow. Confronted with losing what he actually wants because of his obstinance, Will gives in, offering his acceptance of the union along with a three hundred fifty pound dowry. Discovering that it was all a ruse after the wedding, acrimony explodes and Sean refuses the dowry, dragging Mary Kate home in tears.The first half of the film was about Sean finding his place in Inisfree. The second half is about Sean earning it. Mary Kate refuses the marriage bed because she feels like she's unmarried without her dowry and that Sean is a coward for not fighting for the money that's hers. He, on the other hand, has very good reasons for not wanting to get into a fight. He has a secret, having been a successful boxer with a shot at the title who killed a man in the ring, an experience that has turned him away from using his fists for any reason. The two, after their marriage, must find a way to fully belong to each other. That means that Mary Kate needs to learn the importance of the money to the marriage, and Sean needs to learn to fight for whom he loves.This pair of character movements is carried out with the deft humanist touch that Ford had shown so effectively in films like Submarine Patrol and They Were Expendable in a war context. In 1920s Ireland, it's reduced in scale but not effect. What Sean and Mary Kate end up doing with the money when they do get it just fills my heart with happiness. It's the perfect place for them to end up.And then Sean and Will fight, and it's a rollicking fun brawl that goes across the countryside and into the town with a pause at the local pub, all while the whole town, including the visiting Protestant bishop, bets on the winner with Michaeleen trying to keep track.Ford was never exactly in love with color photography. Like Billy Wilder, he largely preferred the artistry of black and white over the use of color, but when Ford used color, he really used it (it still makes me sad that Drums Along the Mohawk's original Technicolor negative is lost). The Quiet Man is marvelously green from beginning to end, visually underlining the idyllic nature of the story. Ford's cinematographer, Winton Hoch, apparently didn't like how green it was turning out, helping to feed Ford's doubts of the production contemporaneously, but I love the results (and so did the Academy that awarded the film Best Color Cinematography, along with Ford's fourth Best Director win).Wayne himself is perfect as Sean. He carries a certain sadness and passion for his past and his wife while pairing with Victor McLaglen well in terms of size and spirit. Maureen O'Hara is wonderful as Mary Kate, spirited and quick-tempered but also able to effectively sell the change in perception she has in terms of her husband's apparent cowardice. The supporting cast are always fun to watch, given amusing business like Ward Bond's Father Lonergan trying to fish while also chastise Mary Kate for her failures as a wife.This probably is the easiest film to love in Ford's large filmography. Bright and colorful while consistently entertaining from beginning to end with delightful performances from the leads on down, The Quiet Man is old school Hollywood filmmaking at its best.

For John Ford a triumph.As the Academy Awards, USA 1953 bears witness.John Wayne, a wonderful performance, as in all his films.Maureen O'Hara, as ever great.John Ford favorites, Victor McLaglen and Ward Bond give good support.Barry Fitzgerald just the right character for the role.And as does Arthur Shields And Ken Curtis in a small role.I note various negative opinions.Seems not everyone likes this film.This movie is one of my favorites since the 1950s.If one accepts it as intended, it is perfect.

reviews.review_title: A film even a feminist can love
reviews.content: What is wrong with people? I'm a lifelong feminist and professor of women's history and I LOVE this film. For goodness sake people, it is a reworking of Shakespeare's _Taming of the Shrew_ that shows how women manipulate patriarchal society. Yes there is patriarchy, but the point is how Maureen O'Hara manipulates John Wayne and her brother. How can you not love the beauty of Ireland, the hotness of Maureen O'Hara and John Wayne as the perfect deadpan Yank? His "John Wayneness" is as perfect for representing the quintessential American, as Barry Fitzgerald is as always as THE Irishman. I was SO peeved that this film was not being shown this St. Patrick's Day. It is my annual tradition. YouTube to the rescue ;)

A friend recommended this movie to me this week. I find the movie sort of snuck up on me... 50 minutes in I wasn't that into it, I found it cute but a bit meandering... but it was immersing me into a way of life and seeing the world... until I began to really understand these characters intimately and care about them, for good and bad, warts and all... So many great moments, I love when the man says "saddle his horse he says!" and starts humming the music to come in the very next scene... I saw another movie do that not long ago, but can't remember what it is, no matter, then Maureen jumps a little obstacle course on the way back home ;) Or during the fight at the end when the bucket just keeps getting bigger and bigger throughout the course of the fight until they look like they're fighting in a flood. Maureen O'hara truly is the best thing about this movie, her power as an actress was undeniable. John Wayne is more looks than great acting ability. What an extraordinarily brilliant film.

"Ford's greatest triumph." That was the tag-line Republic used in promotion of its new release, a movie that almost didn't get filmed but for a swap John worked with Herb Yates to make two Westerns as box-office insurance (It was the 50s). So after years of seeking a backer, the great director's pet project finally came to fruition and proved the studio's top money-maker. John's Grapes (40) and How-Green (41) are more powerful, The-Searchers (56) more epic and Liberty-Valance (62) more melancholy, but if I had to pick just one from his vast catalog to send up my spirits, it would be The-Quiet-Man.What will impress you early in this tale of an American boxer (Wayne) who's tragedy in the ring has sent him on a journey of self-discovery, back to his native Ireland, is the film's visual delights, for this is a Technicolor tour-de-force in league with Pressberger-Powell's Black-Narcissus & The-Red-Shoes. But that's only after Oscar winner (80-Days) and 24-times nom'd Victor Young's unforgettable music has set your feet to tap and heart to soar as soon as that Republic eagle, production logo appears. The moods they create can be miles apart, a "good stretch of the (sprockets)," you might say, but the great opening scores (The-Third-Man) have a common trait: insta-tell. All you need hear again is one bar to know right away, good times are straight ahead!Beautiful and fiery Maureen O'Hara is both John's wife and emotional sparing partner, Victor McLaglen his well-propertied nemesis with "a tremendous right and jaw of granite," Barry Fitzgerald his cabbie, matchmaker & town gossip, Ward Bond his fly-fishing priest who succeeds where politicos have failed (Protestants + Catholics) and Arthur Shields as Rev. Playfair, a former boxer himself turned tiddlywink enthusiast, Bishop's drinking buddy, "Snuffy" to his charming wife (Crowe) and confidant to our troubled protagonist who proves the film's sage and Sean's guiding light.You may notice by movie's end that there is more money that ends up on the floors of pubs and wedding parlors in Inisfree than finds its way into the Bank of Ireland. That's hyperbole, for sure, but if the The-Quiet-Man is any indication of life on the island (Irish Gaelic: Sleeping-bag = "mála codlata"), one could probably eke out a pretty decent living just by gathering specie off the floors of such establishments, that is if 'Red' Danaher had tied the knot with the widow Tillane and together issued sufficient "spawn" to populate the green Isle with the Squire's hot-headed habit for sending coins to flight.And if you be wondering what it is exactly that Mary-Kate is whispering to Sean at movie's end, let me just say, an Irishman worth his weight, even one molded in America, won't be giving up his shillelagh as Trooper did, excepting for one thing and one thing only, and it AIN'T the drink, mind you! Planting is what they'll be doing and not rose bushes this time. Now go on and be about your business (4/4)!

reviews.review_title: Good movie for a wet day
reviews.content: This is a good movie for a wet day and you're stuck indoors, it has dated well and to those who think it is awful and it is not Irish enough for you - Lighten Up. All the characters have their moments, but the part that steals the show for me is little Michaleen.
John ford ... i cant explain to myself that director of grapes of wrath and quiet man is the same one ! No story no drama no tension no plot ...just fooling around village and boxing !

reviews.review_title: The film in which the American and the Irish John Ford came together
reviews.content: John Ford is known for his Westerns, in which John Wayne often played the leading role.Sometimes however he did not deny his ancestry from the old continent, more specific Ireland. I think of films like "The informer" (1935) playing in Ireland or "How green was my valley" (1941) playing in Wales and starring Maureen O'Hara.In "The quiet man" both sort of films come together. John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara both have a leading role. The film is situated in Ireland but contains themes from the Western genre.More specific the message of the film is that a real man stands up for his rights and is willing to fight if necessary. Someone who tries to keep the peace at all costst is a weakling.Sean Thornton (John Wayne) is not a weakling but nevertheless tries to keep the peace for most of the film. This has something to do with his past as a professional boxer, a story element wich has definite similarities with "Body and soul" (1947, Robert Rossen).The film contains some beautiful images of Connemara and the matchmaker Michaleen Oge Flynn (a superb supporting role of Barry Fitzgerald) makes it even more Irish. All prejudices regarding the preferences of the Irish for the pub and singing are confirmed. We have to keep in mind however that John Ford was of Irish descendancy himself. You can't have prejudices againt yourself, can you?

I think John Wayne should have stayed with the western genre. This doesn't fit him. He is not a good actor, he only has got just one side, one face, etc. That's why he could be great in western. They don't need much there, just looking into the camera long enough without a blink and one is hired. But even if there had been someone else in the lead role this story still would have been absolutely boring.

About a different time and culture, this may seem "problematic" to some people today, but it's a heck of a lot more than just what it "appears." Using the parlance and mores of the time, it creates a believable love story between two people and problems that relate to their worlds, not silly plot points that are simply there for "reasons." They don't make 'em like this anymore so stuff your modern views and enjoy this for what it is, was, and will always be.

This has been one of my favorite movies for many years. First saw it with my family. My father was so taken with it that we went to see it several times in first and second run theaters as well as drive-ins(remember them?). I can remember that during the scene where Michaeleen sees the broken bed the whole audience was laughing so hard that nobody could hear the line. When I saw it on TV many years later I was amazed at the "Impetuous! Homeric!" when I would have sworn it was "Holy Mother Of God!" I guess that wouldn't have gotten by the censors in 1952. How times have changed, and not necessarily for the better. I know that modern viewers probably are upset by the sexist treatment of women that goes on in the plot but even in 1952 we were not that bad. I think the plot was probably set in the early 1920's and not 1952. That isn't an apology but just an observation by an old fan of John Wayne and Ireland.

reviews.review_title: One of the best John Wayne movies
reviews.content: This is one of the best movies in the illustrious careers of everyone involved. John Wayne made his mark as a cowboy but this film is one of his best, being teamed with Maureen O'Hara and Victor McLaglen it really couldn't miss, add in John Ford as the director and you've got an instant classic. It's amazing that the studio thought it would flop but I think everyone involved with this movie had to know they had something special on their hands.There isn't a weak link in this entire film, the stars are perfectly cast and give flawless performances as do all of the supporting actors, not just Barry Fitzgerald, his brother Arthur shields, Ward Bond and Mildred Natwick there are people with only a line or two who deliver them perfectly. Ken Curtis also adds a lot with his wonderful singing, it's a movie which would be less enjoyable even if just one person were removed. The Quiet Man is flawless and a film that never gets old, even the main story about a man who longs for a simpler life in a simpler place is something that resonates even in today's world.

After accidentally killing an opponent in the ring, Sean Thornton (John Wayne), an Irish-born American heavyweight, hangs up the gloves and vows to never fight again. In an attempt to bury the past, he starts anew by going back to Ireland to reclaim his family farm, falling in love with Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara); however, after they marry, her brother Squire "Red" Will Danaher (Victor McLaglen) refuses to give her her dowry, leaving Thornton conflicted between staying out of trouble while failing to defend his wife or doing his part in righting a wrong while likely having to use his fists to end the feud. If you enjoy lush scenery that director John Ford and Winton Hoch are excellent at capturing, then this is by all means a must see for you. Also known for its comedic showdown brawl at the end. Not much else going for it though, and John Wayne is John Wayne.**½ (out of four)

reviews.review_title: A John Ford/Wayne romance for the Irish.
reviews.content: It's certainly worth viewing and gives you a real sense of what life was like post War Ireland. For me the best, stand out scene was a traditional cross country horse race (which I'd never seen before), although the hulking Wayne would have been a highly unlikely jockey. The rest is kind of like a U.S love letter to their promised land but it's all innocent and beautifully shot. John. W, gets to show his (almost) sensitive side and lovers of John Ford will rate it highly.

reviews.review_title: A not so quiet journey into manhood
reviews.content: This film covers a plethora of themes and tackles many of them brilliantly, but the most pertinent one centers around that of entering manhood by overcoming one's fears. Certainly not an uncommon theme in literature & film, but the unique way it's told here is subtle and resonated with many.One of the most memorable shots in cinematic history is the punch which triggers the flashback to Sean's boxing match. Splendidly shot and edited, John Ford reveals to us the source of Sean's present fears, all without breaking character perspective. Finally at that point everything clicks: he never wants to enter another fight again, for fear of accidentally killing yet another man. Indeed he is afraid of his own strength.His fear makes complete sense and is something a general audience could understand and sympathize with, even if not empathize (most people have never killed). We don't look down on Sean for this and how it haunts his soul, and yet still ANY fear, even if completely rational and sane-minded, must be overcome to truly transition into becoming a man.The killing is what drove him to return to Ireland in the first place, akin to a boy retreating into his mother's arms (in this case the mother being his motherland/birthplace). Both Miss Danaher and her brother pick up on this, and don't respect him until he proves his mettle by finally fighting again. One might think on the surface that the big fight scene is just two dudes duking it out for the purpose of action, but it is actually the culmination of Sean overcoming his fears and entering manhood. A happy ending to a fairly dark but wonderful tale.

It is doubtful that the Idyllic Ireland represented in John Fords tribute to the homeland ever did exist but that in no way detracts from a glorious film. Great character performances from the likes of Barry Fitzgerald and Victor McLaglen complement the two leads and it is possible to watch this film and actually believe that John Wayne can act.There are themes here if you want to find them; sexual frustration, Old world versus the new but this is best viewed as simply a good story wonderfully shot and performed. If nothing else you should view this film for the best fist fight in cinema history lasting nearly 15 minutes of screen time and covering about two miles of beautifully photographed Irish countryside. One word of warning though. This film is probably best avoided by sensitive feminists.

reviews.review_title: A Masterpiece of Storytelling in Technicolor
reviews.content: John Wayne, Maureen O'Hara and Director John Ford in a movie that the major studios deemed "too small" to make. (The DVD has a few flaws due to the age of the original, notably transfer flicker and framing, but, otherwise well done.) A wonderful story with almost all exteriors actually shot in Ireland. For anyone who thinks that John Wayne "can't act" I insist that this movie shows that he indeed can, and Maureen O'Hara certainly brings out the very best in him. The story of an ex-championship American prize-fighter who returns to his ancestral Irish homeland to begin anew after regrettably killing his opponent in the ring. The "courtship" between "Sean and Mary Kate" is something to behold and thoroughly enjoyable. Barry Fitzgerald steals every scene he's in, although his "Irish Brogue" makes some dialog hard to understand. The last nine minutes are priceless between Sean Thornton (Wayne) and Mary Kates brother, played by Victor McLaglen. Most of the principal characters perform their own stunts!

One of the best films ever made - a classic I enjoy over and over again. Maureen O'Hara and John Wayne are perfectly matched as the two lovers drawn together by their equally passionate natures. The look they give each other when they get wrapped around the post at the train station tells the entire story of love challenged by tradition. I look for it every time I watch this film.The supporting cast is delightfully led by Barry Fitzgerald as the local tippling matchmaker. Bound to observe the proprieties of his office - his horse's propensity for drawing up short at the local pub is his greatest challenge. But as he so wryly tells the horse 'Maybe you have more sense than the rest of us' Anyone who enjoys spectacular scenery, well drawn characters, compelling story telling and everything Irish will be captivated as I was.

John Ford and John Wayne were one of the best duos in Hollywood. Wayne was known for his staunch conservative values While Ford was a staunch Liberal.
However, it was the Liberal who went and served his country during the Great War. Something John Wayne failed to do. Ford refused to help Wayne get in the military after Wayne realized he would one day have to face his fellow actors who put their life on the line serving in his place.
I think it was Ford who saved Wayne's movie career. The Quiet Man is a wonderful chick flick but regardless, it is a wonderful display of Ford's genius and Wayne's acting which brought the success to the screen.

reviews.review_title: One of the Best Films Ever Made
reviews.content: Not sure where the 7.8 rating comes from, with 10 being the most common.If your a fan of the Duke, Maureen O'Hara, John Ford, Ireland, romantic comedies, beautiful scenery, or inspired storytelling, "The Quiet Man" has them all. Any one would satisfy. Together, they are sublime.Ford's ode to his native land has American prize fighter Sean Thornton returning to his native home in Innisfree, to find a new life after killing a man in the ring. He immediately falls for fiery colleen Mary Kate Danaher, who's brother is against the pairing due to Thornton buying the White O' Morn land he's eyed for years. Leprechaun Michaleen Ogr Flynn sets to the matchmaking, where American and Irish ways clash. When Mary Kate insist on her dowry that her brother won't give, the sparks fly.Not. To. Be. Missed.

This is one of my favorite Maureen O'Hara and John Wayne movies. I found it charming and romantic and I can watch it over & over again. I really enjoy the chemistry between these two fine actors. I loved where the movie took place, the cinematography, the supporting actors, Maureen's strong Irish character. I recommend this to all who like Maureen O'Hara. I feel who better to play the role than a real Irish person to bring such credibility to the character. I also enjoy Ms. O'Hara in all the "swashbuckling" movies she starred in (i.e. The Spanish Main, The Black Swan and Sinbad the Sailor). Also amongst my list of favorite classic Christmas movies, I loooooove Miracle on 34th Street it's right up there with It's a Wonderful Life. No one can do the original "Miracle" justice (referring to the TV remake that was done).

reviews.review_title: Not such a quiet man or quiet performance
reviews.content: I don't normally award such high praise, but this is the Duke at his finest. The Quiet Man is one of those fantastic movies that you have to watch every time it comes on TV. Duke is at his best in this movie and looks the part of the young boxer he plays with an iron jaw and rugged good looks. Maureen O'Hara, his love interest, is also at her best in this offering. She's a wonderful looking Irish red head who plays the hot tempered sister of local squire and land baron, Will Danaher, very convincingly. Danaher is played by the inimitable Victor McLaglen, a thespian seldom accorded the credit he deserves. Duke's character is Sean Thornton, an Irish American prize fighter who accidentally killed a man in the ring and retired from boxing. He moved to his family's old neighborhood in Ireland to escape the memory of the accident. Eventually he marries Mary Kate Danaher, Maureen O'Hara's character and the two settle into married life. Unfortunately, Squire Danaher does not pay the anticipated dowry to Thornton and, as a result, Mary Kate is absolutely humiliated. Sean chooses to ignore the insult rather than get into a physical battle with Danaher. His wife sees this refusal as cowardice (Sean won't tell anyone of the dead boxer in his past) and does not react in a loving and wifely way to her new spouse. To keep her, Sean approaches Will Danaher and demand payment of the dowry. A fight ensues between Danaher and Thornton and it no doubt qualifies as one of the finest and also longest battle sequences in film history, with the entire town, including resident and visiting clergy attending the spectacle. The film ends on a positive note with Sean, Mary Kate and Danaher having dinner together. John Wayne (The Duke) is an American icon. We won't see his likes again. Looking about, I don't see another actor with the stage presence and body of work to which Duke lays claim. I've watched him from his early work in Stagecoach all the way through to his final movies and believe that he is a uniquely American icon. He had to wait virtually all of the way through a fantastic career before he finally won a long overdue best actor Oscar. I don't think we'll ever get over this man. He represented the very best qualities that we expect of American heroes.

reviews.review_title: My all time favorite, and John Waynes best !
reviews.content: If this film doesn't make you proud to be Irish, nothing will. Maureen O'Hara is the spitting image of what I imagine my grandmother was like.  Lots of spunk.  Favorite part was when the pub owner said "drinks are on the house" and the place fell silent, the customers couldn't believe it.  Then after a pause, he says, "well they are"', and when Barry Fitzgerald says to Maureen O'Hara, " when I drink Whiskey I drink Whiskey, and when I drink water I drink water", after she offered him some water with a drink.

Simply one of the most entertaining movies of all time. We always watch as a family around St Patrick's Day. Great director, great cast, great scenery. The troupe of actors Ford uses in many of his movies only add to the interest the film generates. The supporting characters are so independent of Wayne and contribute to the depth of the film. And it is such a unique film for John Wayne - not a western or war venue --- but a love story. The scenery from the countryside adds so much to the flavor of the story. And especially the race alongside the seashore.There are so many lines that are memorable and quotable. But, the true genius of Ford lies in the footage between the lines. The looks that O'Hara and Wayne exchange are classic.This is one of the few films that gets better with age.

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece of the old,golden Hollywood years.No sequel,please!
reviews.content: Simply a masterpiece, a "homeric" masterpiece.John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara are here undoubtedly at their best.Barry Fitzgerald is really great.The whole cast is superb.Great songs.Wonderful landscapes;(it's Ireland!After all!).IRELAND forever!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Great John Wayne Classic with Irish Charm
reviews.content: If you love classic movies this one to see. The story can be found in many movies but the simplicity and warmth of the acting is enchanting. Respect, love and honour all come back in this classic. John Wayne plays a retired boxer who wants to enjoy a quiet retirement back in Ireland but as always a beautiful fair maiden spoils it all. After a long and tardy battle with her brother regarding the Dowry it eventually will bring a smile to the viewer face.Brilliant movie for the anyone who likes to watch a classic

I purchase very few movies and own less than twenty total. I consider this movie a MUST own and watch it at least once a year during the Christmas holidays.It is truly a magical movie. The attraction between Wayne and O'Sullivan is electric. McLaughlin is magnificent as the older brother. The casting for the rest of crew is perfect.When you need a nostalgia fix, this movie will provide it and to me, ranks with Casa Blanca, It Happened One Night, Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, and White Christmas.John Ford's masterpiece!

This is a beautiful movie to see. It would have to be if it was directed by John Ford. Ford used all his artistic talent to execute the mood in this film. It is full of impressive scenic shots, amazing colors and exciting scenes. The type of scenes, that make this romantic drama even more exciting. You feel the energy coming off of John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara, who is a genuine Irish actress, so she was perfect for this part. The chemistry between Ford and O'Hara matches the complete differences between the two of them.John Wayne is cool in this film and O'Hara is a knock-out. This is a classic story about an American, who arrives in Ireland to claim his inheritance. He just manages to run into the best looking lady in all of Ireland. It is a typical, simple, easy story to digest. I use the term "typical" loosely, because the legendary John Ford, with a typical story, creates a world that is not typical and gives us a great look into a 1950s Hollywood drama, centered in Ireland. This film and Ford's work on this movie is the stuff of Hollywood legends. This is a must-see film and a perfect one to watch for St. Patrick's Day.8.0 (B- MyGrade) = 8 IMDB.

reviews.review_title: Such a Great Movie...one of John Ford's best!
reviews.content: This movie is so timely. I believe that John Ford touched the essence and tradition of a people with this movie. All of the actors played their characters superbly. There was continuity and timing in this wonderful play. Well worth watching! I loved watching the interplay between Fitzgerald and Wayne. Such respect between the two actors. Ward Bond had become one of my favorite character actors in the cinema. If you haven't see this movie, watch for the scenery and vivid colors in this movie. I have noticed that John Ford is very meticulous when it comes to location for all of his pictures. John Ford also loved to carry the same ensemble cast to various projects (Wayne and Bond). If you haven't seen "The Quiet Man" or any other John Ford pictures, please do yourself a favor and check out this director.

reviews.review_title: John Wayne Maureen O'Hara in Irish tale
reviews.content: 1952 The Quiet Man directed by John Ford was filmed in Ireland and is a beautiful two hours of Irish music and Irish scenery. Add John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara and you will experience a joyful film. Her brother and Wayne have a good old fashion fist fight which changes everything. A film not to be missed.

reviews.review_title: Missed a ten by one point
reviews.content: And the reason is miscasting Victor McLaglen and Ward Bond whose rolesshould have been switched. Victor was just "TOO OLD" for the part whichreally came to the fore in the fight scene. He should have played thepriest leaving the role of Red Will to Ward Bond which would have beentruly believeable. Ward Bond would have been just as comedic andmenacing as Vic, maybe even more.Other than the above.WHAT A DELIGHT! Kudos to all connected with thatwonderful

reviews.review_title: Beautiful film, romance is lacking, plot is too thin
reviews.content: It's a movie that's close to perfect in some areas and then less than stellar in other areas. Depending on what you enjoy in movies you may think it's just fine or a great work of cinema.Firstly, the cinematography is exquisite. It's close to perfect really. You will need to watch classics like Lawrenre of Arabia to find anything like this. The movie is made to show off an Irish rural community presented from its best possible side. You see horse riding in nature, a glorious church, cozy cabins, old time bar, old locomotive. There is a lot to look at here in all scenes. It's glorious and a nice watch just for that. Only negative note on this are some sound stage scenes where we see various actors watching some spectacle and it's clear the sky behind them is not real.Second great factor is Maureen O'Hara. She's spectacular as the love interest. She carries a less than stellar plot. As soon as John Wayne spots her and we see her acting like a low IQ fool you are bound to fall in love with her character too and understand his interest. She looks fabulous, but that alone can't keep your interest for a full movie. She acts like some silly girl who has never seen a man be interested in her. She hides around corners and stares at him and refuses to marry him unless her brother says she can. I frankly don't know if people like her exist, but such a silly and cute role in a movie is perfect to keep the engagement high. Spectacular acting. As Wayne tries to follow their weird customs to marry her and we see her acting and the beautiful landscape we are engaged enough no matter the plot being a bit too simple.Now, unfortunately the plot is quite thin for a 2 hour runtime. Even for 1:30 hour the plot would be thin. For 2:09 hours you keep asking yourself where it is going and what the point is. We see Wayne move back to Ireland from USA. Later we learn that he killed a boxer in the ring and wanted to escape the mental anguish. But then apparently he's a millionaire too or something yet we never understand why he is filthy rich. Was he a top boxer? He even burns money at one point. In one scene he throws away his hat. In another he destroys his own door and bed. They overall seem to not much care about property. They spill beer everywhere and in another scene Wayne destroys another door. It feels like a silly cartoon that never cares to explain itself. All the men in town like to shout a lot and look silly which leads to some bad acting. But they are side characters.
