The plot overall is basically a guy coming to a fun little cozy town and marrying a perfect woman while fighting her brother. That's it. It's very well made and looks great. No scene is boring as such. And you are interested till the end. But there are quite a few scenes and events I didn't get. It feels like either I didn't get the humor, didn't understand their accents, or maybe there is some old costum I didn't understand. Not even sure what it is. The time period is also not clearly defined. I'm looking at it and it could be anywhere from 1910 to 1952. The most advanced technology we see is a locomotive and a phone. Apparently it's the 1920's, go figure.Wayne is a cool character. But I always find him a bit crude. He's never smart about anything in his movies. Stuff just comes to him because he is crude and hits first which is lazy filmmaking, but does look movie cool. I don't like how he throws his wife around. Unfortunately the marriage starts on a bad foot and 50% of the marriage scenes are them fighting. Initially her just spotted her and thought she looked hot and that's that. There is nothing more to it. They actually don't like each other's personalities; she just wants to get away from her brother. So you really feel like this marriage will end in disaster. At any point it looks like he is going to slap her. And since he's a former boxer it feels that way. Of course she wants to be a good wife in front of the village and won't leave him. But it's sad that he cares so little about her feelings here. He's supposed to be Wayne the man's man, but keeping your wife happy is a man's job and he's largely failing at it. Never saying anything positive to her. Not buying her gifts. Not defending her honor. Of course he does all these things in some ways, but never with any care so it looks like a totally loveless relationship because of him. He's cold, quite violent, and uncaring. She is trying her very best and it's way more than he does. I guess not all relationships are the same, but you wonder how she could fall in love with him in just some months when he acts like a jerk. He's not the right man for this romantic role. Luckily most modern actors largely know how to play the romantic lead too. The script could have made him more caring in some way to make up for his style of acting. Because of this I don't think it's a strong romance for teen girls. This is not a "dreamy" man. But what do I know? I just wanted to see the relationship work and it didn't. There was no care or romance which is a huge fault. Maureen O'Hara carries the movie on her shoulders, but it's not quite enough.

The transfer is terrible, especially on the alleged "collectors edition." One of the worst I've ever seen actually. Somebody thought the Irish countryside was so pretty they amped up the hue and contrast making much of what you see blurred and overcolored. Too bad, fans deserve better. And no Dolby either, just enhanced sound,,,whatever the hell that is?BTW, they are ALL like this. If you want your own copy you're better off taping it from an AMC/TCM broadcast. The VHS version ain't all that hot either.

I originally saw this film back in the year 1988, when I was only eight years old.  It wasn't until about seven years later, when I was 15, that I saw it again.  At first I didn't know that I had seen it before but as I watched the film it began to come back to me.  The rich imagery and memorable lines had all stuck with me despite my young age.  To this day I still watch it almost every St. Pattricks day as a tradition.  It makes me realize that John Wayne was an actor with a lot more skill and depth than most gave him credit for.  This film (along with "True Grit") should be considered one of his best.

Not only have I seen the movie, I own the movie and just returned from Cong, Ireland where the outside scenes were filmed. In my heart the beauty of the story and Ireland are the same. Timeless. The people there are so proud to this day 53 years later of the movie and the notoriety it has brought to their town. The train station is in Ballyglunin, the bridge in Connemara, and the town in county Galway. It is a wonderful place and so is the movie and the story it tells. The castle where the actors stayed is now a grand hotel. The pasture where Mary Kate was seen herding her sheep is now a fairway on a golf course belonging to the castle. The river is the same with salmon fishing an everyday sport.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of all time!
reviews.content: John Wayne and John Ford made some amazing movies, most which will stand for all time as pure entertainment. Add Maureen O'Hara and you have the makings of the all time best category, add Ireland in all it's glory and you have magic. Pure unadulterated movie magic. Even if you're not a John Wayne fan, this is a fun, entertaining, charming movie. John riding his hunter across the countryside and in the race showed his considerable talents as a rider were not made up in Hollywood.John Ford had the eye for film-making that most directors of this time only wish they had. He made his movies a family affair. His brother, the amazing Francis Ford plays the feisty old man who gets up from his dying bed to watch the 'big' fight. John Wayne had 4 of his children, you can see them all in one scene, look at and near the cart Mary-Kate is in at the race. And I believe even Maureen O'Hara's newborn daughter has a cameo, being carried of course. John Ford's movie family is combined here also, all of the top performers were regulars in Ford's movies. Move over Sam Raimi, Ford Invented nepotism!

If you are interested in conservative and traditional values, this is the movie for you. Always in my top lists. It is an exuberantly photographed production with beautiful Irish locations (Innisfree, a well-known geographical name thanks to its locally produced margarine) . Its subliminal motto is the comings and goings of the protagonist couple, who after a certain strangeness have the possibility of conjugal peace. Between modernity and tradition, John Ford's soft, light and Manichean tone is overly sentimental, not unlike his other, more complex and ambiguous reference works such as The searchers (1956) and The Informer (1935). The American protagonist, Sean's definitive acceptance by the local Irish community will only be satisfied when he finally decides to bow to the codes of tradition, acting vigorously with his wife (in a shameless manner by today's ridiculous politically correct standards) and struggling with her brother. The great filmmaker with this film paid tribute to his ancestors' native country.

Not only is this film a wonderful display of cinematography and acting clout, it also brings to the screen a great story--what movie-making is all about.  John Ford wasn't concerned with demographics, box office sales, or action figure revenues.  He just wanted to tell some really good stories. And The Quiet Man does just that.  With the on-screen chemistry between Wayne and O'Hara, the farcical comedy of Barry Fitzgerald and the breathtaking landscape on which they are filmed, Ford (who received an Oscar for Best Director for this project) draws you into his world of hard-work, good times and tremendous passion.  Ireland has seldom been captured in such a beautiful or accurate way since and (seeing as it was the first American film to be shot in Ireland) displays a world that few have been privvy to see before.

reviews.review_title: Another great picture from John Ford
reviews.content: John Ford is one of the great names of Hollywood, and in this drama he shines once again.Like no one else before him, or perhaps even afterwards, he captures the time periods that he chooses for his films, and it all feels very authentic and thematically intriguing. The acting is incredible as always, as is the script, cinematography, cutting and editing.It is definitely a film that is to be recommended if you have a remote interest in the incredible craft of John Ford's filmmaking, and it is definitely an incredible film for the ages.With John Ford, you can never be disappointed. Give it a watch!

reviews.review_title: Ireland has never looked greener or it's inhabitants more quaint
reviews.content: You could say it's a version of 'The Taming of the Shrew' but it has another ingredient - John Ford's compassion and love of Humanity warts and all. One of John Wayne's best performances certainly not outshone by Maureen O'Hara and Barry Fitzgerald both in excellent form.

Why this film is considered a romantic classic is beyond me.  Ohara and Wayne both greatly overact to create a silly and contrived love/hate relationship built mainly on Wayne's brutal treatment of her.  O'hara plays the role of the typical feisty love interest whose attraction to Wayne seems to be based more on a sadistic relationship than anything else.  Throwing her violently on a bed or dragging her by her arm, Wayne is portrayed as a gentle giant of sorts...a gentle giant whose only way of solving problems is through physical force.  A longer-than-necessary brutal fight between two men, passed off as a playful bout,is evidence enough that a better title for this film would be "The Cave Man".Aside from the socio-political implications of this film, the storyline was uneven and vastly uninteresting.  Although this film was made at a time when audiences drooled wide-eyed over foreign accents, the intricacy of the Irish brogue and wit is lost to the confining framework of Hollywood dialogue. Character development (aside from Wayne) is week.  The Priest and constant flow of old Irish guys makes for an interchangeable cast and scene list.O'hara's character is so one dimensional that she seems barely human.  Her constant worries concerning the terms of her rushed marriage only add to this.  If this story is supposed to be about love, then why does O'hara seem to put everything before it?  I couldn't help but wonder why exactly Wayne like this woman so much.  Their relationship seemed quite empty and unexplained, as if most of their courtship took place off screen.I found this film trite, boring, meaningless, and regressive in its view of women.

This nice film is introductory to Irish culture. It has a great screenplay and acting is well above average. The outdoor scenery is beautiful. The film is blended with nice scores throughout.As for the subject matter, many things about the marriage ritual are similar in the rural parts here in Turkey and I believe in many other places on earth. So you'll find many things to feel for.

reviews.review_title: One of the all time best
reviews.content: John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara could not have been a better set of actors for a Irish picture in Ireland. Maureen O'Hara was so lovely and nice. John Wayne was the best of those days. What a seasoned cast with Ward Bond, Victor McLaughlin. This movie couldn't fail to be a success, one of my favorites and makes me feel a bit secure that people, at one time, were civil and had such integrity.

This film brightens my day whenever I see it. In fact, now I'm reminded of it I'm going to try to watch it again real soon. The combination of American and parochial Irish values and characters has a touch of real life about it. John Wayne's quiet manliness in the film isn't very PC these days but can be taken with a nostalgic pinch of salt.The fighting, acting and comedy are first rate. Watch it again.

reviews.review_title: Using stars to make an art film
reviews.content: Everyone has already pretty much said everything that could be said about this movie. The Leonard Maltin featurette on the DVD was also a great summary of what went into making this film. What strikes me as interesting about The Quiet Man is that it's an art film starring John Wayne (along with several other stars usually seen in popular films). I give most of the credit for pulling this off to Ford's inspired direction. To be able to take the most typecast Western actor and believably turn him into a washed up ex-pat boxer was a major feat.It brings to mind Fernandel, who churned out mediocre comedies at about the same pace as John Wayne churned out westerns. At the time The Quiet Man was being made, Fernandel was chewing up the scenery as Don Camillo the temperamental priest. But he had played key roles in several of Pagnol's classic films in the 30's and 40's, and occasionally played well later on, under directors such as Verneuil and Autant Lara. You wonder whether Wayne could have done a few more top notch films if he had spent more time out of the saddle - roles more like what Kirk Douglas and Burt Lancaster were playing at the time.

reviews.review_title: The very best of John Wayne
reviews.content: I have to believe this film is the very best that John Wayne did in his long career. John Wayne was not an actor, and as a rule when he went outside the box of playing himself in film he usually got into trouble. ("The Barbarian and the Geisha," "The Conqueror" as examples." But this film put him in a better light than all of the war films and all of the westerns. And the pairing with Maurene O' Hara was fated, just like Gable and Lumbard, or Tracy and Hepburn. This pair was to go on and make a number of films together including his other gem "McClintock." Add to the outstanding cast with Ward Bond, Barry Fitzgerald, Mildred Natwick and Victor Maclaghlan among others and the feature soars. To top it all off is the beautiful Irish countryside. (And yes, if you look on a map of Ireland you will find Innisfree in the northwest corner of the country. I can't say enough about this piste. Thumbs up, all the way.

reviews.review_title: The best John Wayne movie EVER!
reviews.content: The entire movie is full of wonderful actors giving wonderful performances -- all set in the beautiful Irish countryside. There is something for almost everyone in this film, one of the best films ever made.

reviews.review_title: The single best John Wayne/John Ford films. Perhaps the best of all films period
reviews.content: This film is a constant amazement to me.  The visual imagery and story line are a single work of art.  The character portrayals are astounding. I believe I can smell the countryside and taste the beer in the pub and I feel transported to another time and place when I watch this film.  I love all the people as friends and I belly laugh more and more each time I watch it. John Wayne is a real life person in this film and I really like him.  His bigger than life wooden characters that comprise most of his career are not evident here.  (I like John Wayne, just believe I see his limitations) The John Ford troupe are at their best in this one. It is a family film.  It is a guy film.  It is a women's film (in my opinion) Boy, what a film!! It is a movie I turn to for a spiritual pick me up.  Please view it and enjoy.

Maybe it's because it wasn't a Western or a War film. In the day, that's all that was available to watch and that's what the public wanted. A western to take them out of their war-torn lives and war films to promote patriotism.To me, it was refreshing to see something else with John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara. They are a great screen couple that complimented each other.It's a wonderful tale of a man that goes to Ireland to start his life all over again after an awful boxing bout that brought the death of a man that he liked.He didn't expect to fall in love with an Irish girl but he did and what a time he had dealing with her brother. Will Danaher felt threatened because Sean Thornton was just as tall and as big as he was. Will thought that Sean was going to replace him as the "best man" of Inis Free. Sean Thornton was a peaceful man by nature but did what he had to do to survive at a young age. He had no intention of doing anything but living a peaceful life in the home he was born in.This film was light hearted and comical and dramatic in its own right. I've first taped the film from AMC Channel commercials and all but now I own the DVD. I will never part with it.

reviews.review_title: My life's only tradition is an annual March 17th viewing of The Quiet Man
reviews.content: This is Sean O'Fearna's most deeply personal film and the one on which Ford and Wayne cemented their relationship. It tells a story of a reality that never existed except in the dearest wishes of the film maker.
A tender love story from day's gone by. John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara are wonderful together and the supporting cast are just as much the stars as the two leads are.

reviews.review_title: This is a refreshing comedy film
reviews.content: This is a refreshing comedy film, full of strong Irish folk color, cheerful and lively, especially in the final country duel one, showing the director's outstanding talent in comedy. It has beautiful pictures, melodious music, and a funny plot. Therefore, even though it is old, it is still a good work that does not lag behind the times. The film won the best director award at the 25th Academy Awards in 1952.

Perhaps the greatest of all American films,great cast and great cinematography.John Wayne was never better.John Ford,the director,apparently made this movie as a tribute to his ancestors.It is both a comedy, and a drama. It is also a love story. Perhaps even more than these, it is a character study.The year that it was made,1952,The Greatest Show On Earth won the academy award for best picture. This is probably the greatest injustice in the history of these awards.It is a very sentimental story,and it is an extremely beautiful movie visually.Fine performances from all the cast.It also contains what is usually regarded as the greatest fight scene in the history of movies. This is a movie that can be watched over and over again.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies ever made.
reviews.content: Everything about this movie is great. From the acting to the scenery, it's a joy to watch. I never get tired of watching it. Truly one of the best movies ever made. Was there ever anyone cooler the the Duke? MaureenO'Hara is beautiful. And just look at the wardrobe from this movie. Back then Men knew how to dress. The clothes John Wayne wore would look as good today as they did then. Also, the authenticity of the movie, how "Irish" it really is, make it even better. The cast of Irish players in this movies lends to that authenticity, and the movie was made in a way that lets that come across as genuine, not corny as other movies that try too hard to be Irish. This should be on every top ten list out there.

reviews.review_title: The Easy Way to Win an Oscar ...
reviews.content: ... just shoot your movie in the Irish countryside.  Instant Cinematography Oscar!

This is my all time favorite movie. I don't re-watch movies, but when this is on I watch. Beautiful cinematography, good story, great fight scenes. What more could you ask? John Wayne & Maureen O'Hara were made for the parts. Classic irish story about an american boxer who goes back to his familial home in Ireland.

reviews.review_title: Basically, a simple, quaint twin flame movie set in my baby's ancestrial homeland!
reviews.content: Set in my girl Joan Jett's paternal ancestral homeland- beautiful Ireland! Filmed in County Mayo, Ireland, to be exact, which is the place her father's people came from!This is one of the most visually stunning films I've ever had the pleasure to behold! Maureen O'Hara sparkles like a jewel in Technicolor, John Wayne is handsome, and the whole cast helps bring the film to life.The most remarkable thing about this movie to me, is how gorgeous it is, just on a natural level. No special effects, just a superbly special setting that is the lush Irish countryside, and it makes the movie! The Irish certainly are a blessed bunch to live within such grand beauty- which stands out even more, thanks to the art of Technicolor.Tonally, this film is light- a light romance, comedy, and drama. It isn't a romcom though, it's more a scenic character study, Tempers flare a bit too much for my taste off and on throughout, but overall, this is a soothing, gentle, very simple movie, which I like.Another thing I like about this movie is its twin flame elements. Anyone who knows anything about the concept of twin flames and watches this movie, will probably recognize the mirroring of a twin flame relationship going on, and other twin flame elements, such as it being a relationship between two people who come from different places, and also that what one wanted to stay away from, the other was desperate to have- so this illustrated the exposing each-other's wounds and making you face them element of twin flame relationships. The two main characters mirrored each-other in how significant (in a good or bad way) money was to them, and through that, they were forced to face their own fears and struggles around it.This film is a must-see for any fan of its stars and the Technicolor films of the olden days.

reviews.review_title: Why Isn't This Movie Rated Higher?
reviews.content: I would have though that this move would be at least an 8.5 or 9.  One of the all time great American movies, this is a work of love for John Ford, which also in a way acts as a pean to the great unrequited love of his life, Katherine Hepburn (in the character played by Maureen Sullivan).  Height of their career performances by all involved, especially Sullivan, Barry Fitzgerald and John Wayne.  The movie is especially worth watching for fans of Wayne & Ford's Fort Apache movies (She Wore a Yellow Ribbon, etc), since all of these movies have almost the same core cast of the usual John Ford regulars.  All in all, a brilliantly heartfelt film that can be watched at any time of the year, Irish or not.  It's about heart, it's about family and it's about how a man and a woman sometimes just have to stand up for themselves.  That, and it has the best use of a foreign language in a film: "Father, can I say it in the Irish?"

This movie shows Maureen O'Hara and John Wayne creating the same type of magic they had on screen in "Rio Grande" and that they would have again in several other movies. This is a movie that I love watching, along with other John Wayne movies.

reviews.review_title: Excellent film makes you feel good
reviews.content: I love this movie . it is timeless. Has it all. It's the type of movie that makes you feel good. I have seen it multiple times and enjoy each time. A must watch ! you will not be disappointed. Makes one yearn for less complicated times.

reviews.review_title: Truly one of the greatest films ever made
reviews.content:
The rolling hills of the emerald isle are mere scenery for one of the greatest fight scenes in modern movie history.The magic of the direction by john Ford is shown in the truly magnificent cast, and not just the main character's of Wayne and O'Hara but in the simplest of roles for the irreverent Barry Fitzgerald and the immaculate Ward bond.The story rolls along with wit and charm that could only be found in the quaint Irish villages used as the backdrops.Wayne a prize fighter home from the states after a fateful boxing match, Victor McLaglan the bullying brother of the sister Wayne falls in love with at first sight only to be thwarted in his chase by the big bad brother.
Wayne enlists the help of the whole village in deceiving McLaglan into allowing him to court his sister and the rest they say is history, leading to a fist fight right through the town which ends only where it could "In the Pub"If you only ever watch one film this year take this out and enjoy a bit of the "Old Irish Blarney"

This is one of my favorite movies.  I love the Irish folklore, culture, the scenery, and the humor.  John Wayne never looked so handsome, especially in the cemetery when he and Maureen O'Hara finally get to be together.  The fight scene has to go down as one of the funniest and most memorable in screen history. Just ask Steven Spielberg - he incorporated parts of this movie in ET.

reviews.review_title: Sean Thornton returns to Ireland to leave his troubles behind...only to find that trouble will always find you.
reviews.content: This masterpiece is one of my all time favorites.  It tells the story of Sean Thornton (John Wayne), "a quiet peace loving man come home from America", and the woman he falls in love with (Maureen O'Hara).  The chemistry between Wayne and O'Hara is always magical, but is at its best here.  The supporting cast, Barry Fitzgerald, Ward Bond, and Victor McLaglen, is one of the best I have ever seen. It represents some of John Ford's best work, and this is the movie for which John Wayne should have won his oscar.  Beyond a doubt, this is his best performance.  This movie is a must for anyone who loves movies, or is a John Wayne fan.

reviews.review_title: John Fords best. The chemistry of the actors/esses was unique
reviews.content: They don't come any better than this one. John Wayne, Barry Fitzgerald, Victor McLagla and Maureen O'Hara were at their peak and even the supporting cast seem to be hand picked for the part. Yes "Squire Darlin" it was great

reviews.review_title: If Only Panavision Had Been Available in 1952...
reviews.content: Is the only way this beautifully shot and classic film could have been improved. John Ford took many of his stock performers that he used in his westerns to make this wonderful story about a retired American prizefighter whom returns home to his birthplace in a small town in Ireland to make a new life. It's a story that is part comedy, part fish out of water built around a romance between John Wayne as the fighter and the incredibly lovely Maureen O'Hara as a local lovely who sweeps Wayne off his feet. Wayne and O'Hara were one of the screens great romantic pairings, making 5 films together and they were never better than TQM. Great film to watch anytime, especially to celebrate St Patty's Day!

reviews.review_title: Johns greatest break the mold role.
reviews.content: This is simply the greatest example of John Wayne not doing a western. It is as timeless today as when it was originally produced.Incredible Irish imagery and seamless acting by all of the principals makes this a true must see. Even if you hate it you'll want to see it again!

Overall, The Quiet Man is a classic for a reason. The performances from the great John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara are brilliant for their chemistry, passion and raw emotion they bring to the film. Barry Fitzgerald plays a brilliant part (Michaleen) and brings such humour to the narrative. The writing, music, everything about this film was amazing and it's such a feel-good watch with a heart-warming romance at the centre. A great film from one the greatest filmmakers ever.Quote - "When I drink whiskey, I drink whiskey; and when I drink water, I drink water" - MichaleenRating - 5/5

The best word to describe The Quiet Man is "delightful."  A rare treat in the film world.  I encourage all to get a copy of this classic, sit down for an afternoon in front of the small screen, and prepare yourself for an unforgettable experience.

The Quiet Man, a movie centered in County Cork, Ireland is an older romance movie that took many twists and turns.  Sean Thornton, the main character, moved to Ireland from Pittsburg, PA after killing a man. He then fell in love with his neighbor, Mary-Kate Danaher. Her brother, Red Will Danaher forbid the relationship because he wasn't fond of Sean because he out bid him for his land.I give this movie a 4 out of 5 star review because it was always exciting and it was just a great movie. There was adventure, romance,and it always kept you wondering what was going to happen next. So Does the guy get the girl? You'll have to see it to find out!

This is a movie that the Wife and I can both enjoy, and have every other month for the last 20 years.  We love the magic John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara bring to the screen.  While the acting is decidedly 50s, the traditional issues raised and cultural differences make for many laughs - good fun.The overriding theme is that love will conquer all.If you enjoy John and Maureen in this movie, try McLintock and Big Jake.

John Ford and John Wayne: a guaranteed good watch. Throw in Maureen O'Hara (Mary Kate Danaher), and this time you end up with my favorite John Wayne film. That may partially be because this film is not the John Wayne of Westerns or wars. His role in The Quiet Man is like no other role he ever played, and he shines. He did make other comedies (such as the 1963 quasi remake of this film, McLintock), but here he is legend. The story sets up with Sean Thornton coming home to his family's native land holding in Ireland after accidentally killing a man in a boxing match in America. His psyche is clearly bruised as a result, and he has a beautiful homestead to help him recover. Enter O'Hara, and the film morphs into a loose remake of The Taming of the Shrew. Touching and sentimental throughout, the film captures the viewer's attention and never lets go. That's even though we are sure of the eventual outcome. Witty at times, hilarious at others, Sean and Mary Kate capture our hearts along with some of the local characters played to perfection by a superlative cast, including Ward Bond as Father Lonergan, Victor McLaglan as Mary Kate's brother "Red" Danaher, and Barry Fitzgerald as Michaleen Flynn. There is some stunning on location filming, but the studio sets are not at all off-putting, because Wayne and O'Hara are the focus no matter where they might be courting or rebelling. I have seen this film more than a dozen times, and when I do decide to watch it, I clear out two hours for uninterrupted pleasure. The writing and dialogue are precise and imaginative, and Ford's direction is at his peak. He was the master of cinema story-telling and oh what a story this one is. The whole experience has never once seemed trite or stale. Just good old fashion entertainment. No one should go through life without seeing this film at least twice.

Somewhat problematic, but super sweet. This movie would never be made today, but not only is it hilarious, it also taught me quite a bit about marriage.Two completely opposite people must somehow learn to get along. It depicts a passionate but at times toxic relationship that somehow makes it over a really rough patch. And there's a few lessons learned along the way...

reviews.review_title: A Wonderful View of Early 20th Century Irish Life
reviews.content: The perfect movie to watch on Saint Patrick's Day - every year. The casting is right on and the direction fantastic. One can't help but to be in a good mood after watching it. It must have been a labor of love for all involved.

Only the great John Wayne could make any movie great viewing.  I gave it a powerful 7/10.  I prefer O'Wayne in his Western element as Wayne, though. Ireland is no place for the Duke.  Maureen is absolutely great in this film, too.

reviews.review_title: Wayne and O'Hara in John Ford Rom-Com
reviews.content: John Ford regularly had humor in His films, even though most were action stories, like westerns. Many of these had John Wayne in them, and He could be funny. But this is a straight up Romantic Comedy, set in Fords' love letter to an Ireland that no longer existed, but is fun to watch. Wayne made very few films that were considered Comedies, "Without Reservations", with Claudette Colbert, being one of the few exceptions. But this film is a sentimental, pleasant, Funny Romance with the beautiful Maureen O'Hara. Enjoy! Don't get too wound up by the casual misogyny. In the historical period of this story Women were often treated like possessions. This is only historically accurate, not a endorsement of the behavior, which Waynes' character found ridiculous.

I found this movie quite incredible, but at the same time, it was also one of the most disturbing movies I have ever seen. In the movie, Sean must prove his love to his wife by fighting another man to show her that he is not a coward. Earlier in the movie, a man had told Mary Kate that Sean was a better man than she thought because he thought that he did not have to prove himself in that manner. Would Mary Kate only love Sean if she felt he had proven himself by fighting her own brother? I think that is what makes the film so disturbing. These people have grown up through tradition of proving themselves strong through physical force. I think Sean was a much stronger man in the beginning of the movie, when he would not fight than in the end.

Watching this as I've only just discovered that it's the film which E.T. Is watching on the TV as he's building his communicator. It's also in that scene where Elliot 'free's the frogs' & screams 'We've gotta save him!', the emotional response to E.T's discovery that he could be saved. This is also the segment that Elliot has his romantic encounter, which is masterfully scored by incorporating Victor Young's score (from The Quiet Man) interwoven with John Williams original E.T. theme which combines to make it overwhelmingly romantic & absolutely magnificent. I thought it impossible to love E.T. more, but this has made it transcend to a new level completely.

It is time that this film attracted a spot of revisionist criticism.  I enjoy it every time .. and yet there's much to object to, beyond the stereotypical portrayal of the Irish.  Sean Thornton is only a hero in our own terms. He wades into a community, conveniently getting to buy his childhood home, then flouts every cultural rule of the place: behaving improperly outside church, running away from the chaperone during courtship, tricking his fiance's brother in order to marry her, misunderstanding the importance to his wife of her dowry, and grossly mistreating her in public. Yet it all ends happily. It would be nice to conclude that this film is an ironic comment on stereotypes and the behaviour of a brutal, culturally insensitive man in the grip of a fantasy about his Irish roots Unfortunately, I'm sure Ford meant it straight. The vigour and the scenery add a gloss that makes a very questionable story highly watchable.

I agree completely with the above reviewer's comments. But one of the other things that I enjoy watching is the new world versus old world conflict between Wayne's and O'Hara's characters. It's interesting to see that what he considers to be provincial and unimportant, she regards as part of the bedrock of her life. If I said anymore I'd give it away. It's one of the few films that I never tire of seeing. And it's not just Wayne and O'Hara, either. There are stellar performances from all the rest of the cast, too. The one that tickles me the most is by the one who plays the matchmaker. He also plays the lead role in "Darby O'Gill and the Little People" (a Disney film). Movie producers just don't seem to be able to assemble as solid a cast today as was for "The Quiet Man". Enjoy!

reviews.review_title: The right mix of Humour and Romance
reviews.content: John Fords 'Quiet Man' is No.1 in my top 10 all time movie greats. With just the right mix of humour and romance, and of cause that fist fight.I have one question that I hope someone could answer. Where in Ireland was the Quite Man filmed?

After reading the comments of some of the people who called 'The Quiet Man' dated and out of touch, I have a comment: After 50 or so years, what movie isn't? The Wizard of Oz? 'Birth of a Nation'? Lighten up! It's a semi-comedy about life in Ireland before World War ll. It's not supposed to reflect on life anywhere today. Values were different back when this movie was first proposed, so It couldn't possibly not be dated. The movie is a great romp through a peaceful town full of stereotypical characters shaken up by the arrival of an expatriate from America and stars some of the best actors of the period, all from John Ford's private troup. (It seems John Ford had all Irish character actors in his stable) Same characters, different names. If you didn't like 'She Wore a Yellow Ribbon' you won't like this movie. Finally, The movie is just fun. Not to be taken seriously, and not to be taken for more than it is: good entertainment.

Warning: Spoilers, spoilers, spoilers. This is such an old movie I figured it wouldn't matter too much. Read this after you've seen the movie for an avid fan's view of it.The Quiet Man is my favorite film because two major themes are the role of a woman in a traditional society and dealing with anger constructively.Mary Kate Danaher is not quite what we've come to think of as a "traditional" woman. She is fiery, not passive or submissive although she clearly understands her role as a woman and lives within it. She knows who she is and what she wants and resists being pushed around as much as she can within the limits that have sustained her culture for centuries. The dowry is the key to her role in society. It's a tradition that gives her dignity. Mary Kate delivers my favorite feminist speech in a film when she comes home after the wedding. The most memorable line in the speech for me is "Without my things about me, I'm still a servant dreaming amongst the things that aren't my own." Without the dowry she's been handed over from one man to another with nothing of her own, so she feels like a prostitute. Makes sense to me.The other theme, anger management, explains Sean Thornton's refusal to fight for the dowry. He believes he can't fight without being mad enough to kill. To keep his wife he has to find a way to get her dowry without fighting and possibly killing her brother. He finally figures it out. Play the Irish game. Call the brother-in-law's bluff. "It's your custom. No dowry, no marriage." he says to her brother. After the brother grudging hands over the dowry Sean _and_ Mary Kate burn it in front of the brother-in-law and the whole community. They all know it was never really about furniture or money. When there's no more reason to be angry the two men slug it out just to see who's the better fighter. And its a great fight scene. The fight scene alone is worth watching the movie.Technical aspects of the film are also wonderful in my opinion. I especially love the rich, beautiful technicolor images of Maureen O'Hara in Ireland. The role of Sean Thornton seems made for John Wayne. (It probably was.) But its what the film says to me that keeps me watching it over and over.

John Wayne's finest film. Maureen O'Hara as well. What a redheaded beauty. I've been watching this film since I was a child. I'm 61 now. Never tire of it. reviews.review_title: There is a dark side to this classic!
reviews.content: Although 'The Quiet Man' remains one of my favorites, there is a dark and angry underside in this beautiful fairytale. Like all of John Ford's movies, it's a study of manners.  If you remember Ford's great film 'Fort Apache', with almost all of the major actors from 'The Quiet Man', it presents the tension between the Irish and the Anglo-aristocracy in the old army.  Just watch the formality of the Post dance, or the confrontation between Henry Fonda and Ward Bond in the latter's house. If you watch Richard Harris's performance as Bull in 'The Field', you see Red Will's character in this film, but without any comic elements.  What both films portray is greed for land, suspicion of outsiders, the appeal of self-destruction, and the resolution of conflict through violence. In 'The Quiet Man', the hero-stranger proves stronger than his local strong-man nemesis, and a happy ending is ordained.  In 'The Field', the stranger is not stronger than the local land-owner, and is murdered.  At the end, almost everyone is dead. I think 'The Field' is more honest in portraying those elements Greek tragedy which continue to underpin the realities of Irish life.

reviews.review_title: Irish At Their Best: Dinking, Fighting and Having Fun...
reviews.content: I've been visiting Cong in 1998 with my wife, shown as Inishfree in The Quiet Man, and was astonished to find that the small town hadn't changed since 1952, except for electricity and asphalt covering the main street. It's all there and they have a museum with lots of memorabilia from the movie. I hope I can go back again... People are very friendly and there is even a guide, a young woman, who knows everything about the film and tours you around the locations. I had to do it by myself with my wife because she was busy elsewhere, which was no trouble because we even know the dialogs by heart. It was very exciting to find the places where some memorable scenes were shot: the "sleeping bag" episode, the bicycle escape from the match maker, the Cohan Bar, the church...It is one of my favorite movies. I had to buy a DVD version because my VHS copy was worn out. It had always become a black and white version of the colorful original...

This is Wayne & Ford's best collaboration ever. In fact, from a true John Wayne fan, it is his best ever. If you do not know the history of this film I suggest you read up on it. Filmed on location & in Technicolor it is visually amazing. I cannot say enough of the film except live it, learn it and for God's sake add it to your library. It's a must for everyone.

If you enjoy a simple story line with great acting and directing, this a movie for you.  John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara add the romance while a talented crew of character actors add the color to a great tale set on the Emerald Isle.  This is especially fun to watch if you're Irish.  Mandatory viewing in my house on St. Patrick's Day.  Draw a pint of Guinness, sit back and enjoy the show.

In 1957. When I was a seventh grader, we read the original short story version of "The Quiet Man." and it remained one of my favorite stories until my father and I saw John Ford's seminal production of the film adaptation together. John Ford's direction packs together an entire Irish village to serve as the crucible for the deliverance of the man who in the text was Shawn Kelvin, but who in Ford's hands became Shawn Thornton. I guess that the powers that be cannot resist changing the classics once they have purchased the literary property, and of course, no one can stop them. John Wayne is at his very best and so is Maureen O'Hara. The suspenseful buildup to the confrontation between Thornton and Danaher consumes much of the movie plot whereas on the page the event is tightly compressed. Now 69 years after that movie was made, I watched it again this morning. And not only has it lost none of its charm and suspense. The final bonding of the boxer from Pittsburg and the colleen and her brother seems now to be near perfect poetic justice.

Normally I would not recommend watching a film because of its violent content but with this film I make an exception.The fight between John Waynes character and Victor Mclagens is the best i've ever seen on film.Forget guns,knives and john woo this is how it should be done.Sorry all you youngsters[stereotyping,sorry] out there no one gets killed,mutilated or shot but do yourself a favour please and watch this it wont incite you to violence but it might just make you smile

reviews.review_title: Who said this was a racist movie?
reviews.content: I saw remarks of this movie from people who said it was racists against Irish, women, etc. Well, I am for one, Irish, and that was the culture back then in the 1950's. It was a well thought out movie and light-hearted. No supreme political message, no nothing. Just a love story about an Irish-American and an Irish gal who's culture clash. It ends up that John Wayne and O'Hara go through troubles with their marriage due to money, culture difference, in-laws, etc. But it all works out at the end and no one dies, everyone is married/happy and no supreme political correctness to destroy the movie's atmosphere of love, laughter and humor. If you want to escape reality, and go back to 1950's Ireland, then watch this movie. If you want to watch a movie with political messages, and are offended by light heard Irish stereotypes (which are true because I am Irish) then this is not the movie for you. people who voted 1/10 for this movie 'cause it was "racists" against Irish should ask me first if it was racists because I AM IRISH

I like movies. Some I see once and that's enough.  Some I see twice or even three times and that's enough.  But once in a very great while, a movie comes along which stays with you forever and you can watch it again and again and never tire of it.  The Quiet Man is that movie. Watching it is like being put under a spell or like you have been hypnotized.  You memorize every line, every scene, the timing, the music, every little thing about the movie until it becomes a part of you.  I don't like this movie - I love it.Other good love stories: Last of the Mohicans and Roxanne

I couldn't help feel nostalgia and mild dismay as I watched this film realizing that the albeit highly romanticized pastoral life depicted so warmly here is essentially extinct not only in Ireland but all over the "developed" world. The movie is set in the mid-twentieth century but might as well have been put a hundred years earlier. No radio, no TV, no computers, few cars, just one phone(!) and a regularly late train. Instead, horse and buggies, plows, fireplaces, and a community with shared values and vibrant social intercourse . How politically incorrect such a world now seems with its caste structure, all-pervasive religion and subjugation of women. In the end, Thornton (Wayne)  although smitten by this world tries to resist its essential ways but is absorbed into it and by it, and thus transformed from American to Irishman.  Hard to imagine that such a world has disappeared so rapidly and completely and in so short a time : the transformation has thus worked the opposite way, with Irishmen  now becoming Americans, metaphorically speaking. This for me lends a somewhat tragic sense to an otherwise comic film.

This is John Wayne's best performance, notwithstanding his Oscar for "True Grit."But everything else about the film is a cut above, including direction and a brilliant casting job.Nearly 50 years later, "The Quiet Man" remains a wonderful film to watch.

reviews.review_title: John Wayne - rode hard and put away wet.
reviews.content: John Wayne, at forty-five, is looks far too old for the role in a movie that has much to recommend it - including gorgeous scenery, fine direction, and marvelous portrayals by the supporting cast. What it is not is a romance.I've watched this film a number of times. Even before Turner Classic Movies and various streaming platforms, it showed up on television every St. Patrick's Day. I love the stars, Wayne, O'Hara, and McLaglen in other roles but Wayne is so physically abusive toward O'Hara and dismissive of her that it made me uncomfortable even when I was a child. reviews.review_title: By far, the best John Wayne movie ever made.
reviews.content: This is by far, the best John Wayne movie ever made. This movie showcases Wayne as an actor, not just an icon in a cowboy hat. The Quiet Man is the movie he should have won the Oscar for, not True Grit. He has tremendous presence in this film, not to mention a great supporting cast. Barry Fitzgerald, Maureen O'Hara, (the under-appreciated) Victor McLaughlan, and a cast of bit players make all watchers feel as if they are in the little town of Innisfree. John Ford uses the picturesque setting of Ireland to its fullest beauty and allows his characters to look at home. The Quiet Man is an Oscar worthy movie because of its writing, directing and cast that acts as if it was family.

Classic film that ranks as one of the very best of the John Wayne/John Ford films.  This cast is superb across the board, with Wayne giving one of his best lead performances as Sean Thornton, a man returning to his birth place of Ireland after a tragic incident, hoping to start over.  Its counter to many of his other performances in that he avoids conflict most of the movie, while also getting to show off his comedic & romantic chops.  He's matched perfectly by Maureen O'Hara, one of the great actresses of the Golden Age of Hollywood, and between her looks and feisty personality, its no wonder Thornton falls in love at first site.  Behind the camera, John Ford (who won an unprecedented fourth Best Director Oscar for this) crafts a brilliant romantic comedy about life in Ireland, with a great cast of local actors along with subtle nods to the political conflicts cast the time (the IRA and the Catholic/Protestant conflict are addressed).  It all builds up to one of the greatest and funniest fights ever filmed, resulting a pure movie magic from beginning to end.  Easily one of John Wayne's & John Ford's best films, which by default makes it one of the best films ever made.

Almost everyone agrees on one thing about the 1952 Oscars: That Cecil B. DeMille's punishingly long blockbuster three-ring soap opera The Greatest Show On Earth did not deserve to win Best Picture.  The Quiet Man  I personally feel should have got the nod Best Picture for 1952 .  It stars John Wayne as Sean Thornton, a former heavyweight boxer who returns to fictional Innisfree, Ireland to reclaim the family farm. There's a sensitive, complicated romance-with independent-minded Mary Kate (Maureen O'Hara), sister of local bully Red Danaher (Victor McLaglen, one of Ford's best company players)-but the real attraction here is Ford's masterful maneuvering of tones and his fluid handling of a large cast of colorful characters, qualities which also defined his iconic (and then-underrated) Westerns. Shot partly on location in Ireland and designed in the lushest greens ever squeezed out of Technicolor, The Quiet Man is a movie that isn't about a whole lot, but yet seems to contain so much-from Wayne's easygoing charisma to the notoriously protracted climactic fight to the febrile, film-noir-like flashback to Sean's boxing days. The Quiet Man is on of Wayne best films and his made possible by beautiful spitfire Maureen O'Hara .

I'm willing to bet Wayne didn't get an oscar nomination because he was a patriot and sympathetic to HUAC's work. I still hear the bugwit lefties whining about the pinkos getting their just deserts. Even though the KGB released documents showing how widespread Communist sympathy was among the Hollyweird. Not much has changed on that account. The place is still full of crap excuses for Americans.

And why all the poorly matched process shots when the company took the trouble to go to Ireland in a day when filming on location seldom was done? Yes, the Technicolor cam was a beast. But still ... This is simple, naive'ish filmaking that seems to have fans. John Ford doesn't impress, tho' there are legions who have a different take on him. The behind-the-scenes story of getting this picture made actually is more interesting than the picture itself. In the Age of "Downtown Abbey," this looks pretty simplistic ... a vehicle for the stars and for the Technicolor process, new at the time.
The Quiet Man is a family tradition every St. Patrick's day, and the film is indeed disarmingly charming in both its wry humor and sentimentality.

John Wayne versus the overly conservative courting traditions of Ireland...sounds like a 5-star blockbuster premise, doesn't it? Well, not so much. My reaction to The Quiet Man was not very positive, and I stalled out and had to restart the movie more than once. The entire plot is just so bland and uninteresting to me that I'm surprised I persevered to the end. At this point I'm wondering if can muster the willpower to explore any more of Wayne's films because I have not enjoyed his performance yet in my first 2 experiences with him. He is a very stiff actor, and struggles to become a convincing romantic lead here. However, despite all my protestations to this film, I did enjoy moments. There were certain actors who were very good, especially Maureen O'Hara (even if I found her character annoying.) There were also some of the minor characters who gave me a chuckle, which I needed more of while watching this movie. The best part of the film, despite all the frustration I felt up to that point, was the final confrontation which somehow hooked me and I was anxious to see how it would end. One other thing that is worth mentioning was how well-restored the visuals were in the version that I watched. It truly captured the luscious beauty of Ireland. All these lovely things are nice to have in the film, but they just weren't enough to make me like The Quiet Man. I have a sneaking suspicion this is a movie I will quickly forget, and will wonder if I ever actually saw it.

Very much a film of its time this movie is just a grand show of patronizing misogyny. Aside from the silly Irish traditions (treated humorously) the moment when you know that the couple are over their problems is when John Wayne orders his wife to cook him dinner and she cheerfully obeys. Sexism in films doesn't usually bother me this much, but it's all played for laughs which makes it oh so much worse. Everything from butt slapping to grabbing his wife and throwing her into bed is treated as a grand game. At one point a priest even tell O'Hara off for slapping Wayne since she should wait til they're married so he can hit back. Yuck. There is a certain extent to which older films must be judged by their own cultural standards and the viewer's own prejudices forgotten, but this entire film is in such poor taste that its appeal is entirely lost to a modern audience. There is a certain extent to which I can respect this film aesthetically, but on the whole I can't bring myself to like characters who come from such a macho culture that I cannot understand them.

Perhaps I *gasp* don't like John Wayne.  His strutting and posturing, long the quintessence of manhood, seem to me the vain attitudes of a caricature rather than a character.  I understand that old film actors concentrated more on cultivating a persona than a character for an individual film, but Wayne's persona is neither compelling nor complex.  
The film's plot is contrived.  I followed the story with skepticism throughout much of it until it devolved into the most ludicrous fight scene that I could imagine, and then I just rolled my eyes and waited for it to be over.
What strikes me most is the film's misogyny.  Mary's insistence for her own money and all the male characters' resistance bespeaks of a lack of male respect for female identity and self-sufficiency.  The characters and the film itself wreak of over-whelming male superiority, and when Mary agrees to serve them dinner, I couldn't help but conclude that this was a film condemned to its time.
Overall, maybe there's a film that will make me like John Wayne, but this isn't it.

Before I review this, let me say that my uncle is an obsessive fan of John Wayne. Knowing how big I am on film, especially my growing interest in classics, he always goes up to me and says, "Hey, you need to see The Quiet Man.", or "Hey, you need to see North to Alaska.", or "Hey, you need to see Big Jake.". But the problem is, John Wayne, while he's a fine actor, I'm not too fond of the films he's in, especially True Grit. The only Wayne films that I've seen that are worth 100% are The Searchers, Rio Bravo, and The Longest Day. But, I have interest in watching these kinds of films, so when I discovered a copy of The Quiet Man in my local library, I just couldn't resist. But unfortunately, despite the fact that it's one of Wayne's most acclaimed films, #2 in most critic's list, I just wasn't a huge fan of it, even if it is directed by Wayne buddy John Ford.

John Wayne plays Sean Thornton, an American boxer who returns to his Irish roots to escape his troubled past. Immediately, he falls for the lovely Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara), but soon faces conflicts with her grumpy brother (Victor McLaglen) over the relationship and his decision to purchase his own land that he was trying to buy for himself. When Thornton and the woman marry, Red Will, the brother, goes as far as stealing her fortune and intimidate them both. Sean must reface his troubled past in order to end his troubles.

John Ford is an excellent director, don't get me wrong. He's made loads of stellar films in his career, including the classic film (with Wayne) The Searchers, How Green Was My Valley, and The Grapes of Wrath. But The Quiet Man isn't my favorite.

Here are some things I liked about the film. First, the cinematography is fantastic. Well, it helped that the film was actually shot on location in Ireland itself, which, in reality, which was where director John Ford grew up. Had in been filmed in some Hollywood backlot, I would have given it a lower score. And I'm not kidding. 

I was also highly impressed with the score by Victor Young. It's tense, it's exciting, and it's moving. It managed to get me going when I was struggling with other issues with the film, which I'll get to in a minute.

You may think I have some problem with John Wayne, but no, he's an excellent actor, I'm just not the biggest fan. Here, Wayne delivers, especially in scenes where he discusses his character's troubled past. The scene where we witness a key moment in his past might be my favorite scene, with the stunning camera shots and the actor's facial expressions in the outcome of a certain boxing incident. Maureen O'Hara also stuns as the love interest. I was impressed with the two's chemistry, which is probably why they did so many films together. My favorite moment here is when he grabs her and does a big kiss on her, which was later imitated in the Steven Spielberg classic ET. I was also impressed by their physical emotions, such as a scene where Wayne comforts O'Hara from a storm in a graveyard. I also liked Victor McLaglen as the town bully. He is a pretty good intimidator, and has some excellent scenes with Wayne.

Now here's when I start criticizing the film. My uncle promised me that this film was very funny, but he lied. To begin, this is not a comedy, this is a drama. A heavy, serious, romantic, drama. Yeah, there was some form of comedy coming from the supporting actors, but the comedy felt extremely forced and I couldn't find anything to laugh about, especially when a preacher falls into a pond while attempting to catch a fish. While that would be funny if the person was Charlie Chaplin, it really failed miserably here. If you want to watch John Wayne in a comedy, this isn't it. McLintock is just another John Wayne film away.

Also, why were there moments of song in this? This is not a musical. I thought my uncle hated musicals (well, his one exception was Seven Brides for Seven Brothers, so he claims). The singing in the Irish pub annoyed me and kind of ruined the flow of the picture. Even a drunken Wayne attempting to sing didn't help either.

But the biggest problem I had with The Quiet Man was the film's climax. On the DVD cover, the film promised "the longest brawl ever filmed." But instead, I was treated to a brawl, but instead of physical contact, we witness locals' bets on the outcome and a heavy crowd blocking the way, and like I mentioned earlier, forced comedy that doesn't help the dramatic flow of the film. When we actually do see the actual brawl, one punch, and it's over. Now that's what I call false advertising. Definitely one of the most disappointing, anticlimactic fight scene I've ever witnessed. You know the climax is a big disappointment when the film's most exciting scene is a small horserace in the middle of the film.

So in the end, The Quiet Man has an excellent John Wayne performance, and the score and cinematography were outstanding, the film suffers from some dry, unfunny comedy, some painfully annoying pub songs, and the most disappointing climax a man could ever witness. It had it's moments, but I wasn't completely wowed by the experience

A wonderful movie that couldn't be more perfect, The Quiet Man is John Ford's homage to Ireland, his homeland. This is the quaint Irish village filled with wonderful characters that we all hope that is the backbone of Ireland--the way we want it to be. The Quiet Man is John Wayne's best movie until True Grit, and also stars the beautiful fiery Maureen O'Hara, the Oscar winning Victor McLaglen, and Barry Fitzgerald, without whom no classic Hollywood Irish picture could be made. A great and warmly humorous flick.

A retired American boxer returns to the Irish village where he was born and finds love. A poignant vision of period rural Ireland, The Quiet Man's influence is still felt in today's representation of Irish landscape particularly in American productions. It does have its flaws, particularly in its less then credible plot and an approach much too focused on nostalgia than anything else. But while it may not be the best Ford and Wayne collaboration, though it is one of the most popular and loved, it benefits from stunning cinematography that really takes in the beauty of the landscape and gives the whole production a magical and characteristic air of majesty.

The story is that of Irish American boxer Sean Thornton who returns to the small Irish village of his birth. Distraught after having accidentally killed a man in the ring, all he wants is to live out the rest of his life peacefully and quietly on his family's land, which is no easy task, as he soon incurs the ire of the squire- a local brute who was wanting the land for himself. 

Not only that, but Sean falls in love with the squire's sister, a feverishly traditional and fiery woman who insists that her and Sean's courtship be by the books, which includes receiving a dowry...that her brother refuses to pay. The couple get married, but until that dowry is received, the marriage absolutely won't be consummated.

What follows is a gloriously jolly romp that shows Sean trying to prove he's a real man without always having to resort to violence, which he is of course reluctant to do given his past.

Yes, the movie does perpetuate a few stereotypes about Irish men loving to drink and fight, but it could be far worse. The film has a fun set up, great supporting characters, and, since it was shot on location, it features Ireland in all of its glory with some truly marvelous cinematography.  The music is also quite nice as well, and it's not surprising that this has become THE movie to watch every St. Patrick's Day as a result.

Wayne gives a fine performance, and it is nice seeing him in a role like this where he actual does have to try to act and show off his dramatic chops. He's successful too. Maureen O'Hara basically cemented her career here as Mary Kate the love interest, and for better or worse, she's the embodiment of a gorgeous prototypical Irish lass.  Victor McLaglen is great as her bullying brother, and the great aforementioned supporting characters are superbly played by Ward Bond, Barry Fitzgerald, and Mildred Natwick among others.

Definitely give this one a watch. It's got drama, romance, comedy, action, and really leaves you feeling great inside.

What I really liked about the issues raised in this film is that the film answers how the main character deals with it and also leaves you wondering about the issues yourself. I also really loved the plot of the film. It's very easy to follow and also at the same time doesn't feel over simplified. The Quiet Man is one of those rare experiences that absolutely engrosses you with beautiful scenery, fabulous acting, a wonderful story and a sweet romance that builds to a realistic level as the film goes on. If you love John Wayne films, or even if you're not a fan of John Wayne, this film is a must see. It's a cinematic experience I won't soon be forgetting.

As is so often the case in the films of John Ford, The Quiet Man has a complex narrative trajectory as resolution to Wayne's romantic pursuit proves elusive. The film layers one point of contention and resistance over another: the challenge of 'taming' the stubborn Mary-Kate, the challenge of appeasing her ill-tempered brother, the careful negotiation of and deviation from courtship formality, an array of cultural sticking points, and Wayne's problematic reluctance to use his fists when called to do so. Through it all, the film maintains a robustly playful tone as critical conflicts are defused through the catharsis of alcohol induced showmanship, excess and camaraderie, mocking our trained expectation for a more destructive outcome to John Wayne's personal troubles.

One could argue that John Ford's charming portrait of the dear Irish homeland hasn't aged well, but while The Quiet Man was set in modern times upon its 1952 release, I don't think it was ever intended to be a "modern" film. John Wayne plays Sean Thornton, an Irish-born boxer who returns to his birthplace after he accidentally kills a man in the ring. Upon his arrival, he meets a colorful array of characters, including the fiery Kate Danaher (played exquisitely by Hollywood's Irish lass herself, Maureen O'Hara) and the somewhat bibulous Irishman Michaleen Oge Flynn (the downright precious Barry Fitzgerald). Part slapstick comedy, part character study, part romance, what Ford delivers in The Quiet Man through the great performances from Wayne, O'Hara, and Fitzgerald, and some stunning cinematography, is a shamelessly nostalgic, good-humored, and somewhat misty-eyed memory of an ideal Irish community.

No question, one of John Ford's finest movies and one of John Wayne's best performances. The Quiet man is a quaint little movie that combines a sweepingly romantic story, clever humor, and beautiful cinematography to a perfect concoction of a great John Ford movie. What makes it extra special, is the perfect chemistry between its two leads and suprise! John Wayne doesn't play a G.I. or a cowboy! He really shows his merit as an actor, giving a subtle and sensitive yet still brooding with masculinity take on one of his most perplexing characters. The film is a must-see for all good catholics and Irishmen alike.

The studio originally wanted to shoot the film outside its actual location, but thank god John Ford went to Ireland to shoot this movie! It has to be one of the most beautiful films ever made. A feast for your eyes, the sparkly and rolling green hills of Ireland are expertly captured and the early use of technicolor is flawless. If you need a movie that you can turn off the sound and just appreciate the beauty of the film, I would say that Lawrence of Arabia and this film would both be on that list. 

It is when you listen to it though, that the movie really shines. The film is cleverly humorous with many aspects of Irish culture weaved into its story. The film follows Sean Thornton, a retired prizefighter who goes to his homeland after a fatal knockout leaves his career in shambles. he quickly falls in love with a young woman but their love is soon troubled as her brother refuses to give up the dowry and their wedding is deemed unofficial to Irish customs. The dowry will not be given up without a fight, so Sean must soon come out of his newly pacifist shell and face his enemy through the passion of his love.

John Wayne never really struck me as an actor, but his performance in this movie makes up for even his biggest flops (Yes, even The Green Berets). It was great seeing him play the non-aggressor but as the film builds up to the famous "Queensbury rules" fight, it was still nice to see classic Duke in action. Maureen O'Hara is also a strong performer, she reminds me a lot of my sister in this film so I felt a bit more personally connected to her character. What usually makes rom-coms fail is a lack of chemistry, thankffully this film has perfect chemistry between the couple, which makes for a sweepingly romantic and richly fufilling film.

I am a good Catholic boy, so I automatically loved the Irish culture and the romance was one of my favorite save maybe Casablanca. If you love Ireland, romance, or just want to see the Duke in a non-typecasted role, The Quiet Man is a perfect movie.

The story is a romance centered on the return of a former boxer to his ancestral home town of Innisfree, Ireland. Reuniting with some old friends, making some new enemies, and falling in love along the way, The Quiet Man is a very entertaining film. There is a great balance of humor, drama and action (namely a very memorable fight scene). With a humorous and perfectly written ending, a great cast and incredibly catchy music, The Quiet Man is one of the Duke's best.

A slice of the old country, the little people and the blarney is very much enjoyed in The Quiet Man. It's essentially a western set in Western Ireland but has all the beautiful detail one expects in Ford films. 

The plot follows that of the classic western meets taming of the shrew. 

Stranger comes to town. 
Falls for the sister of the town's most powerful man who is also a tough fighting man. 
Conflict arises between stranger and local tough guy. 
A further conflict occurs between feisty femme and the stranger. 
The inevitable showdown happens.
And the good guy wins the fight and the woman's heart. 

The plot may sound basic, but the beauty of this film is in great locations, fine performances and a cracking script with plenty of the Irish craic. It's the humour and undeniable charm that really carries the movie along and is only interrupted by several beautiful pools of romance in the middle of the knockabout comedy/drama.  

Director Ford may only have had one eye but probably saw much more than those with two eyes and 20-20 vision. It's his eye for the detail that make this movie especially memorable. Throughout the movie you feel like you are in the west of Ireland, almost one of the locals of Innisfree as you go inside the pub, the humble cottage, the church, the farmhouses and join the locals in the rolling greenery of the Irish countryside. 

The first confrontation between Sean Thornton (played excellently by John Wayne) and Red Will Danaher(equally good stuff from Victor McLaglan) has almost everything. 

The romance of the wee Irish pub, the friendliness of the locals once Sean Thornton's identity has been revealed and the music starts - Wild Colonial Boy sung by none other than country and western singer Ken Curtis - Ford's real life son in law as the accordion playing Dermot Fahy. It hardly gets more Irish than this. 

Enter Red Will looking for fight. The brilliant dialogue follows "I said good morning" Sean declares. "Aye but it was good night you had in your mind" Red Will accuses Sean of making an ungentlemanly pass at his sister Mary Kate (Maureen O'Hara). The tension mounts. 

Ford's real life brother Francis Ford plays an old man in the pub and is central to this early scene - acting almost like a referee in between the two hulks of Sean and Red Will. In the end religious intervention in the form of the unlikely but convincing Ward Bond's Fr Lonnigan saves a full-blown fistfight. But it is only delaying the inevitable. The tone for the whole movie is set.

What follows is superb performances and Ford has his usual team in harness here with Wayne and McLaglan leading the way. Maureen O'Hara who plays Mary Kate Danaher is at her radiant feisty best and probably never looked more beautiful in a movie. Then there is Barry Fitzgerald whose character is part leprechaun, part barfly and as the movie progresses he pops up as a jack of all trades - taxi service, matchmaker, bookmaker and even furniture removal man. He steals many scenes with his great acting and his presence certainly adds all the charm you would expect to find in leprechauns. 

It's certainly one of Ford's finest and has an epic fight at the end, which is not brutal, but merely cartoon violence that Tarantino would be proud of. 

So with wild Irish humour, accordion and loud piano music, jaunty Irish pub songs, meaty confrontations, flames of red haired Irish folk and a big fight, you might ask why this film is called The Quiet Man. Well here's the real conflict and the great irony of the title. Sean Thornton is a retired boxer and has returned to his hometown from Pittsburgh to enjoy "the quiet life". He gets anything but tranquillity and has to emerge from his conscience, morals and indeed motives to fight for the right to have a quiet life and a beautiful wife - who is a shrew needing tamed as she prods her man to fight for her pride. 

The Quiet Man is a classic and one of Ford's standouts among his amazing canon of great work. He shows us a post revolution Ireland at it's finest. A movie that never tires through repeat viewings, this is must for the DVD collection and whenever you're feeling down it is a perfect pick me up, just insert disc, press play and let the great John Ford take you to the Emerald Isle and all it's wonder.

Sean Thornton killed a man in the boxing ring. He's ashamed and wants to forget it. He returns to the Irish cottage he grew up in. That's where he finds Mary Kate and wants to wed her. I never really knew of Maureen O' Hara in any other films I can think of, but I gotta tell you she is so beautiful. She notches up my vote for the most beautiful red head ever. Well, that's just my opinion.

The only problem for Sean when it comes to Mary Kate is two things: Her bullying brother Red and her dowry which is the more important to her than anything else. Sean doesn't care for her money. He loves her and that's that. 

The brother on the other doesn't like Sean and since due to some Irish custom, won't let Sean court his sister Mary Kate. Luckily, a few of the locals trick the brother into letting him think that the widow tillane wants to marry him unless Mary Kate is out of the house. But it's on the wedding day where Red discovers he's been had and decides to keep Mary Kate's dowry from her.

Sean is stuck with being called a coward by Mary Kate if he doesn't return her dowry back to her from her brother. And then finally, the ending which is probably one of the most hilarious fights ever put to film when Sean and Red box eachother pretty much all over Innisfree, the small town.

Sean Thornton (John Wayne) travels back to Ireland, the land of his fathers, after being raised in the US, only to find himself in love with the redhead Mary Kate Danaher (Maureen O'Hara). Her brother, however, doesn't take kindly to Thornton, and, as a result, drama ensues. I say "drama", but this movie is so upbeat with its Irish charm and humor, I would say it's a cozy watch if you want to get in a good mood. It is a prime example of the beauty of technicolor, and the wardrobe is on-point. It's not the greatest John Wayne movie, but, by God, it's the very definition of underrated. Even the musical score is fantastic. Good for adults and children alike. Children will find the third act especially fun. And if you're into boxing/MMA, you may very well appreciate it, too. A great film for couples, as well. The way marriage was handled back then is a fascinating subject matter.

rt_summary: After accidentally killing an opponent in the ring, boxer Sean Thornton leaves America and returns to his native Ireland, hoping to buy his family's homestead and live in peace. In doing so, he runs afoul of Will Danaher, who long coveted the property. Spitefully, Will objects when his fiery sister, Mary Kate, begins a romance with Sean, and refuses to hand over her dowry. Mary Kate refuses to consummate the marriage until Sean retrieves the money.
meta_summary: A retired American boxer returns to the village of his birth in 1920s Ireland, where he falls for a spirited redhead whose brother is contemptuous of their union.
